content: Berkshire Hathaway's (BRKB) supposed interest in taking a stake in General Electric (GE) would fit well with Warren Buffett's investment track record, an RBC analyst said.The remarks came after Bloomberg reported on speculation that Buffett might be interested in buying a stake in the beleaguered industrial conglomerate. The billionaire investor dumped his stake in GE in August."In many ways, GE's current situation fits the profile of an ideal Warren Buffett investment," RBC's Deane Dray wrote in a research note late Tuesday."One of his guiding principles is to 'be fearful when others are greedy and greedy when others are fearful.' GE is a 125-year-old iconic industrial brand with strong assets, market leadership in many industries, and a business model that Mr. Buffett understands, but is operating at a steep valuation discount today."He also noted that Buffett told CNBC in January that he would consider buying stock in GE "at the right price." Buffett has also swooped in to rescue other legacy businesses whose struggles tanked their stock prices — namely Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS) and General Electric during the financial crisis, Dray said.Buffett could reportedly take a $14 billion stake in General Electric, Dray said, indicating he could be jockeying for more than 11% of the company. That would make Berkshire GE's largest shareholder.Shares of General Electric rose 1.8% to 13.68 in the stock market today, after popping 4.3% Tuesday following reports on the speculation about Buffett. Among other diversified industrial stocks, 3M (MMM) rose 0.3%, Honeywell (HON) dipped 0.75%, and United Technologies (UTX) lost 0.7%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseGeneral Electric's shares sank 45% last year, amid struggles to rebound from a so-called "industrial recession" compounded by weak oil prices a few years ago. Given GE's breadth in the industrial sector — from locomotives to oil-production systems — it has felt the pain acutely.GE CEO John Flannery has been receptive to breaking up the company and planned to lop $20 billion in assets off its books. The company has also slashed its dividend in half.Dray said that if Buffett took a big stake in GE, the investor could become another voice — along with activist Trian Fund Management — from which Flannery could draw.He also said the favorable reaction from Wall Street was the "predictable 'if Buffet is investing, then the stock could be bottoming' response." But the analyst said any move from Buffett would mean less for shareholders."However, we caution that any investment by Mr. Buffett would potentially be 'expensive capital,' as he is likely to extract favorable terms from GE," Dray said. "In effect, this Berkshire investment scenario would essentially be in lieu of an equity raise, and would likely be similarly dilutive to existing GE shareholders."YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Trump Tax Cuts Help Boost Dividends By Most Since 2012; Buybacks May Hit RecordBoeing 787, Powered By GE Engines, Makes This Historic FlightUnited Technologies Draws Another Activist Investor Amid Breakup TalkBoeing, GE Likely Winners Of This Massive American Airlines Order

General Electric (GE) shares wallowed near multiyear lows Tuesday as two Wall Street analysts soured on the industrial giant's worsening fundamentals, including its credit and earnings outlooks.XJPMorgan analyst Steve Tusa wondered how long credit-rating agencies can "remain on the sidelines with their commentary, seemingly giving GE precious time to work their way out," given a host of problems.Problems dogging the 126-year-old industrial giant include "material changes in fundamentals," little progress on asset sales, delays in revenue recognition restatements, a lack of "clean numbers" and an SEC investigation, according to Tusa. The analyst also pointed out that during the Great Recession, GE was AAA-rated and needed a bailout."So we scratch our heads as to the repeated inertia" from ratings watchdogs, which should start to get more attention, Tusa wrote in a note to clients Tuesday.He remains cautious on the stock, finding GE's fundamentals are "worse than expected" and calling out its "currently unjustified rating." The recent appointment of a Moody's board member to its own board should raise investors' eyebrows, in Tusa's view.Moody's cut GE's long-term debt rating in November, citing "extreme deterioration" in its energy business. The cut from A1 to A2 still kept the company's bonds in the investment grade category. Also in November, Fitch cut its rating to A+ from AA-, still in investment grade.Tusa, however, has an underweight rating on the stock with an 11 price target, down from 14 a month ago.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseMeanwhile, Stifel analyst Robert McCarthy cut his 2018 EPS estimate for General Electric to 95 cents from 98 cents and his 2019 EPS estimate to $1.05 from $1.10. He pointed to continuing challenges in GE's core power segment, expectation for slower overall growth across long-cycle businesses, and material challenges on price or cost inflation.Given GE's current cash priorities, he submitted a "modest proposal" that management consider capping supplemental cash pension benefits for the highest-level, longest-tenured executives. This, McCarthy said, would send out "the appropriate 'virtue' signaling."Shares fell as low as 12.80 but closed up 1 cent at 13.13 on the stock market today. GE stock has lost more than half its value in the past year despite ambitious turnaround plans outlined by new leadership at the Boston-based company in November.A spokesperson responded to the analysts by referring to comments made by CEO John Flannery during a Jan. 24 earnings call."We will maintain a disciplined financial policy targeting 2.5 times net debt to EBITDA and A1/P1 short-term ratings," Flannery said.Additionally, management affirmed they are focused on improving the strength of the company's balance sheet within a disciplined capital allocation framework.They also noted GE ended 2017 with $11 billion cash from its industrial operations and added, "We plan to increase our cash balance in 2018 and exit the year with $15 billion-plus of cash."Among GE's industrial peers, 3M (MMM) and Honeywell (HON) added 1.7% and 1.3%, respectively. United Technologies (UTX) advanced 1.1%. Siemens (SIEGY) lost 0.1%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Why General Electric May Be Most At Risk From Trump TariffsIn Market Correction, Look For Stocks Like Lululemon With These 3 TraitsCan You Spot The Next Big Stock Market Top? United Technologies (UTX) has reeled in Dan Loeb's Third Point, which lands a place alongside Bill Ackman's Pershing Square as an activist investor snapping up a potentially undervalued industrial giant.XLoeb's hedge fund has taken a position in United Tech's shares, Bloomberg reported Monday, after a regulatory filing dated March 23 disclosed Third Point's stake.Third Point has neither revealed the size of its holding nor said whether it plans to seek changes, sources told Bloomberg. But the activist fund unsuccessfully pushed for Honeywell International (HON) to spin off its aerospace business, suggesting it could seek major changes at United Tech.The Connecticut-based company is considering whether a breakup of core businesses in jet engines, elevators and air conditioners could unlock value. Chief Executive Officer Greg Hayes has suggested that he is open to ideas from activist investors in United Technologies stock.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseBoth United Technologies and Third Point declined to comment, reports said.Third Point and Pershing Square aren't the only activist investors ratcheting up pressure on industrial conglomerates to streamline operations.Nelson Peltz's Trian Partners targeted General Electric (GE) and now sits on the GE board. GE has signaled a breakup decision could come this spring, with a key shareholder meeting set for April. GE's sales and profit growth slumped over the past three years, due in part to a severe power market downturn.United Technologies stock jumped 3.5% to close at 126.64 on the stock market today, stemming a 10-day slide. GE fell 1.4%, while Honeywell rose 2.6%, finding support at the 50-day moving average.In a bright spot for the embattled GE, it emerged as the company behind the jet engine that powered a Qantas Airways jet's historic, nonstop, 9,000-mile London to Perth journey over the weekend.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Boeing 787, Powered By GE Engines, Makes This Historic FlightThese 5 Hot Software Stocks Are Showing Strength Near HighsConsider These 3 Defense Giants For Your Stock ArsenalWhy Did These 4 IBD 50 Stocks Shine As Boeing, Alphabet Tumbled?Alibaba, Nvidia Among Five Top Stocks Expected To Accelerate Earnings GrowthBoeing, GE Likely Winners Of This Massive American Airlines OrderIf General Electric Breaks Up, Should You Break Up With GE's Stock?

General Electric (GE) will sell part of its health care business to private equity investment firm Veritas Capital in a billion-dollar deal, GE and Veritas jointly said Monday.XGE agreed to sell its health care technology assets — including revenue-cycle, ambulatory-care and workforce-management software — for $1.05 billion in cash, with the transaction expected to close in the third quarter."By operating as a stand-alone business under Veritas' ownership, we now have the opportunity to further revitalize our product portfolio and pursue complementary acquisitions to better serve patients, providers and payers," said Jon Zimmerman, a vice president at GE's $19 billion health care unit, which makes products such as ultrasound and imaging systems.GE announced plans to exit from smaller businesses such as lighting and transportation last year, including $20 billion in asset sales, as it fights slumping profits that have wiped billions from its market value.CEO John Flannery also has left the door open to a potentially bigger breakup that could encompass sales or spinoffs of its core power, health care and aviation segments into separate public companies.GE isn't the only industrial giant looking to dismantle its conglomerate structure. United Technologies (UTX) is mulling such a move too. And German rival Siemens (SIEGY) recently sold a stake in its Healthineers medical imaging business through a $5.2 billion IPO.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseShares of GE dropped 2.7% to close at 13.12 on the stock market today. Siemens lost 1.5%, and United Technologies retreated 1.9%. Among other industrial conglomerates, Honeywell (HON) gave up 1.4% and 3M (MMM) dived 3.1%.Meanwhile, General Electric signed a contract with Iraq earlier Monday to process natural gas at two oilfields as the country plans to raise its crude oil output.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Why General Electric May Be Most At Risk From Trump TariffsIn Market Correction, Look For Stocks Like Lululemon With These 3 TraitsCan You Spot The Next Big Stock Market Top? Dow defense stocks Boeing (BA) and United Technologies (UTX) soared Monday, boosting the Dow Jones industrial average and aerospace/defense exchange traded funds.The Dow stock took off Monday after Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the U.S. and China trade war is "on hold." The aircraft maker, which is America's biggest exporter, had pulled back in recent months. Worries about a trade war fed the pullback, since China is one of Boeing's biggest customers.In other news, Boeing won FAA approval Friday to use folding wings on its 777X widebody airliner, according to Bloomberg News. The wings are currently used on the Navy's Boeing F/A-18 Super Hornets.Shares cleared a 348.67 buy point of a cup with handle in light volume Friday, if you look at a daily chart. But the proper entry on a weekly chart is 371.70. So Boeing could be considered in buy range on a daily chart or near a buy point on a weekly chart.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseUnited Technologies, meanwhile, rose 2% as it builds the right side of a base. The potential buy point for now is 139.34.The defense stocks' gains boosted shares of aerospace and defense ETFs:Investors looking for a potential faster gain (or loss) could consider leveraged funds, which seek to provide double or triple the performance or inverse performance of the underlying index. Be aware that these tend to be more volatile than their nonleveraged counterparts and usually have higher expense ratios.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:7 Best Ways To Gauge How The Stock Market Is Doing2 New Ideas To Play Top AI, Bitcoin And Blockchain Stocks5 Ways To Gain From Top China Stocks Like Alibaba, Baidu, Tencent

United Technologies' (UTX) $23 billion takeover of avionics maker Rockwell Collins (COL) looks set to win EU approval.The largest deal in aerospace history will clear the key regulatory hurdle, sources reportedly close to the matter told Reuters.It will give Pratt & Whitney parent United Technologies more leverage to resist pressure from the likes of Boeing (BA), Airbus (EADSY) and Bombardier (BDRBF) when they seek price cuts.United Tech expects to close the deal this year, pending regulatory approvals from around the world.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseUnited Technologies shares fell 0.4% on the stock market today. Rockwell Collins lost 0.4%.Last year, Boeing voiced its skepticism about United Tech's $23 billion Rockwell Collins deal.But Boeing now supports the merger as United Tech and Rockwell have signed up for Boeing's Partnering for Success 2.0 supplier cost-cutting initiative. Both Boeing and United Technologies are Dow Jones components.S&P 500 component Rockwell Collins' history goes away back to 1933, when Arthur Collins founded the Collins Radio Company in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.The company was bought by Rockwell International in 1973 after it fell into financial difficulties. The manufacturing conglomerate spun off its avionics division in 2011, creating the current Rockwell Collins.Aerospace giant Boeing has previously voiced concerns about consolidation in the industry. In 2016, the U.S. plane maker and European rival Airbus expressed unease about a Honeywell (HON) plan to buy United Technologies.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Boeing Now Backs United Tech-Rockwell Deal As Suppliers Join Cost Plan How Boeing Helped Force Rival Airbus To Cut Production On This Jet Defense And Aerospace Stocks To Watch And Industry NewsWill These Defense Contractors Start A Bidding War?

Boeing (BA) reportedly ended its opposition to the United Technologies (UTX)- Rockwell Collins (COL) merger.XLast year, Boeing voiced its skepticism with United Tech's agreement to buy Rockwell Collins for $23 billion. United Tech expects to close the deal this year, pending regulatory approvals.But Boeing now supports the merger as United Tech and Rockwell have signed up for Boeing's Partnering for Success 2.0 supplier cost-cutting initiative, according to the Wall Street Journal."At a time of record industry production, it is critically important that we have business arrangements with all of our suppliers that drive increased focus on meeting their cost, schedule and quality commitments to Boeing and our customers," Boeing reportedly said.Boeing shares closed up 0.4% at 331.76 on the stock market today. United Tech fell 0.9%, and Rockwell Collins added 0.4%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThis isn't the first time Boeing has been against consolidation in the industry. In 2016, the U.S. plane maker and European rival Airbus (EADSY) voiced concerns over Honeywell's (HON) plans to buy United Tech, the Journal reported.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Defense And Aerospace Stocks To Watch And Industry NewsWill These Defense Contractors Start A Bidding War?

Home security company ADT Inc. (ADT) reported a surprise adjusted loss for the fourth quarter, its first quarterly report since coming public in January.Estimates: Analysts had expected earnings of 14 cents per share on revenue of $1.09 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research.Results: ADT earned 99 cents a share on a GAAP basis, including a $690 million benefit from the recent tax legislation. But ADT lost 6 cents a share excluding one-time items. Revenue grew nearly 6% to $1.11 billion.Outlook: For the current year, ADT sees revenue of $4.45 billion to $4.55 billion, with the midpoint slightly above the consensus for $4.469 billion.Stock: Shares popped 5.3% soon after the open, but quickly reversed to close down nearly 13% at 8.90, hitting a fresh record low on the stock market today. ADT came public at 14 in January but has struggled since.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseIt has been an eventful start to 2018 for Florida-based ADT, which went public in January, got whacked on news of an Amazon (AMZN) deal in February, and made two key acquisitions in March.ADT priced its IPO at 14, closing 11% below that level on the first day of trading. Shares plunged in the past month, due in part to Amazon's entry into the home security market.The e-commerce giant agreed last month to purchase Ring, which makes a smart doorbell that streams audio and visuals to smartphones.Vertical Research analyst Jeff Sprague said at the time that residential security players face intense pressure from DIY and self-monitoring systems, with Johnson Controls' (JCI) security products business, Honeywell's (HON) home product portfolio and United Technologies' (UTX) safety and security unit likely facing the most near-term risk.ADT itself has been busy making acquisitions. It inked two deals this month, including Acme Security Systems, a privately held security company in San Francisco's Bay Area, and Aronson Security Group, a risk management specialist based out of Washington state.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:IPO Breakout Update: This Hot Stock Still A 'Rise,' But Others DiveAmazon Vs. Walmart: Locking Horns In A Battle For Retail's FutureTech Unicorns Arrive As Zscaler, Dropbox, Spotify Prepare IPO DebutsBest Stocks To Buy And WatchHow To Invest In The Stock Market Using A Simple Routine

General Electric's (GE) free cash flow is at risk of shrinking, putting its already reduced dividend at further risk, according to JPMorgan.X The warning comes after the industrial conglomerate pledged to shed $20 billion in assets and halved its annual dividend in November to 48 cents. GE stock now yields 3.2%."We still see structural concerns in the key Power markets, minimal margin for error on leverage, numerous tail liabilities at both GE and GECS (General Electric Capital Services)," JPMorgan's Stephen Tusa wrote in a note out Tuesday.The analyst noted that proceeds from shedding businesses will go toward the balance sheet, knocking "assumptions that $20 billion of asset sales comes for free, with no lost" earnings before interest and taxes, free cash flow (FCF).Tusa added: "GE's 'normalized' level of FCF looks to be well below $1 (per share), with a plausible case of sustainable FCF in the $0.50 range, just above the standing dividend."On the GE dividend, Tusa takes issue with those who espouse that the dividend yield is above the sector average."The issue is that while it's not necessarily cut near term, it is not growing, and at a ~95% payout on post divestiture FCF, it's still high risk," he said.Tusa lowered his price target to $11 — a level last seen in mid-2009 — saying "$0.50/$0.60 in 2018/2019 FCF does not support a $14 PT."On the stock market today, shares of GE tumbled 4.4% to 14.43, trailing the 30 blue chip stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average. They have lost more than half their value over the past year. Among Dow industrial peers, 3M (MMM) slid 0.9% while United Technologies (UTX) sank 1.1% after briefly trying to recover from India's grounding of certain jets that use  its Pratt & Whitney geared turbofan engine. Siemens (SIEGY) sank 1.8% and Honeywell (HON) retreated 0.5%.IBD'S TAKE: Read IBD's The Big Picture column every day to stay on top of the market direction. As long as the current "confirmed uptrend" — the equivalent of a green light — stays in place, leading stocks breaking above a buy point may have the wind at their backs.Late Monday, General Electric's newly filed 2018 proxy showed that senior management, including past and present CEOs and CFOs, would not receive bonuses for 2017.The bonus was withheld for the first time in GE's 126-year history, and was meant to" hold the senior leadership team accountable" for the company's performance, the filing added.Meanwhile, United Tech's newly filed proxy showed a boost in the CEO's salary and bonus tied in part to the Rockwell Collins (ROK) acquisition.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:If General Electric Breaks Up, Should You Break Up With GE's Stock?How To Invest In The Stock Market: Start With A Simple RoutineUnited Technologies Has Engine Fix For Grounded Airbus JetsGeneral Electric: 5 Reasons Why The Worst Could Be Over For GE Stock

General Electric (GE) shares are set to bottom after painful recent damage wrought by insurance-related charges, a dividend cut and the lowering of performance targets for 2018 and beyond, according to a longtime GE analyst.X GE's recent actions offer "a line of sight to rejuvenated cash flow generation and improving ROIC (return on invested capital) over the rest of this decade," William Blair analyst Nicholas Heymann wrote in a Monday note. He noted the industrial giant intends to exit $20 billion of businesses, had a recent "uneventful" filing of 2017 financial statements, and announced three "highly respected and qualified" new directors to the board.Heymann sees five reasons GE's shares are likely to offer material upside potential over the near and medium term — and could even double in price by the end of this decade:Heymann acknowledges uncertainty in the near term tied to the regulatory reviews and shareholder lawsuits, but believes these may be resolved in "months rather than years," setting the stage for a recovery."As fundamentally adverse news shifts to more constructive positive news as 2018 progresses, we expect GE's share price is likely to normalize at approximately 20 times 2018 adjusted EPS guidance of approximately $1.00-$1.07 per share, which would suggest a share price of perhaps $20-$22," he said.Heymann added: "The largest potential upside for the shares over the next 6-12 months is likely to come from how the company decides to use the proceeds from the divestitures of its $20 billion in assets targeted for disposal."Shares of GE rose 1.5% to 14.64 on the stock market today, putting it among the top gainers in the Dow Jones industrial average. Dow industrial peers United Technologies (UTX) and 3M (MMM) fell 0.1% and rose 0.4%, respectively. Honeywell (HON) edged up 0.6% and Siemens (SIEGY) advanced 0.1%.Use IBD's MarketSmith For Free Until March 11

It is targeting $2 billion of additional structural cost reductions this year and another $1 billion in 2019.RELATED:If General Electric Breaks Up, Should You Break Up With GE's Stock?How To Invest: Learn To Use The 50-Day Moving AverageBlockchain Expands Beyond Bitcoin To Amazon, Nvidia, AlibabaYY Earnings Jump 45% On China's Livestreaming BoomTarget Earnings Miss, Outlook Weak Despite Strong Online Sales GrowthThese 2 Tech Leaders Have Broken Out; 3 More Are Near Buy PointsTwo Top Chip Plays Poised To Break Out: Why They're Risky

Energy stocks and chipmakers were under investors' microscopes early Friday, with the Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq defending solid gains for the week. But futures for all three benchmarks turned lower in Friday's volatile premarket trade.Dow Jones industrial average futures slipped a fraction, despite strong gains from General Electric (GE) following its quarterly report. Other Dow issues held to tame trade. Chevron (CVX) was up top with a 0.6% gain. At the weak end, Procter & Gamble (PG) slipped 0.9%.The Nasdaq 100 also slipped back into narrow early declines, with China's JD.com (JD) and Tesla (TSLA) showing the index's largest early declines. S&P 500 futures struggled to a slight gain, with GE leading, and Honeywell (HON) and Tractor Supply (TSCO) up 2.2% and 1.5%, respectively. Honeywell posted strong first-quarter results. Tractor Supply received an analyst upgrade.Apple (AAPL) slipped 0.5% and three of four FANG stock tech leaders lost ground.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe Dow industrials ended Thursday's session up 1.3% so far for the week, despite two consecutive losses. The S&P 500 held a 1.4% gain, while the Nasdaq was ahead 1.9%. All three indexes have maintained support at their 50-day moving averages, although Thursday's session flashed the first signs of institutional selling since the market launched its new uptrend April 10.Outside the U.S., global stock markets were mixed Friday. Asian stock markets closed lower, led by a 1.5% dive for China's Shanghai Composite. In Europe, leading benchmarks weakened into mixed afternoon trade. Frankfurt's DAX reversed early gains and slipped 0.3%. London's FTSE 100 defended a 0.3% gain.Earnings news was generally positive ahead of Friday's open. On the Dow, General Electric leapt more than 7%. The rapidly slimming industrial giant reported adjusted losses and revenue declines that beat analyst estimates. The company took a heavy one-time charge during the quarter related to its former sub-prime lending business.But it also affirmed financial targets for the year and said it expects proceeds between $5 billion and $10 billion from sales of assets during the year. GE's conference call is scheduled at 8:30 a.m. ET. Company shares are down 20% since the start of the year, and 56% below their July 2016 high.Sweden-based smart phone maker Ericsson (ERIC) erupted to a 17% premarket gain. A 104% surge in first-quarter earnings topped analyst expectations by a wide margin, and marked the company's first earnings-per-share increase in seven quarters. The stock trades below 10.TransUnion (TRU) rung up a 6% premarket gain as first-quarter results cleared analysts forecast by comfortable margins. Management also hoisted its second-quarter earnings and revenue guidance to well above consensus views. The premarket move suggested the stock could score a breakout at the starting bell above a 61.52 buy point in a four-month flat base. But be cautious, not all premarket moves carry over into regular trade.Energy stocks have provided the market with some rising leadership potential as oil prices sit near 3-year highs and are up 13% year-to-date. Crude oil prices were down 0.6% early Friday, with U.S. benchmark crude slipping just below $68 per barrel. Prices may see some effect when Baker Hughes (BHGE) releases its weekly rig count report at 1 p.m. ET.Baker Hughes also reported its first-quarter results Friday, rising 0.2% after beating earnings views, but with revenue just below consensus estimates. Oilfield services heavyweight Schlumberger (SLB) fell 1% after its first-quarter earnings met analyst targets.The chip sector remains under careful watch on the stock market today. Investors are looking for signs of either a rebound or of further losses, a day after the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index dived 4.3%. The sell-off resulted from industry demand concerns raised by guidance from Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) in its earnings report Thursday.Philly Chip Index stocks traded narrowly mixed early Friday. Among the index's biggest decliners on Thursday — MKS Instruments (MKSI) rose 0.3% in premarket trade Friday. Lam Research (LRCX) fell 0.4% and Applied Materials (AMAT) posted a fractional decline.RELATED:Chip Stocks Spread Their Pain To Apple, But One Sector SurprisesFutures Dip As 2 Leaders Tumble; GE, Oil Names Set To Report These 5 Oil Stocks Near Buy Points As Saudis Eye $100 Crude When To Buy Growth Stocks: Draw A Trend Line Across Handle For Early Buy Point

General Electric (GE) faces the most fundamental risk among multi-industry companies from rapidly rising steel and aluminum prices under President Trump's proposed tariffs — and that could chill takers for a business it's looking to shed, a Wall Street analyst said.X GE makes huge and heavy-duty industrial equipment made significantly of metal, such as jet engines for Boeing (BA) planes, generators for power plants and locomotives, Deutsche Bank's John Inch wrote in a Wednesday note. That raises both direct risk in terms of competitive cost pressures and indirect risk in terms of reduced global trade if other countries slap tariffs of their own, he added."While the value/cost of GE's products are heavily weighted to the engineering performance features rather than the raw material costs, we believe that rising raw material costs (steel and aluminum) can nonetheless still pose significant spread headwinds ("value gap") for GE," Inch said.GE countered the Deutsche Bank note in a statement, saying reports on the impact of potential steel and aluminum tariffs on GE's costs are completely ungrounded."Our internal data shows our consumption of imported metals likely to be impacted by the tariffs is minimal," a GE spokesperson said. "We are monitoring the situation as it develops."Deutsche Bank's Inch cautioned that GE's international rivals in oligopolistic markets could try to gain market share by leveraging higher U.S. metals prices, while GE customers would likely balk if the company tried to re-price its order backlog higher. GE has $134 billion in backlogs tied to its power, oil and gas, and renewable energy segments, according to its 2017 10-k report.Inch also warned that the rail business GE seeks to sell or spin off could become less attractive to potential buyers as metal input costs rise. That's particularly so "given already tough competition from the Chinese (e.g., CRRC) and cyclically depressed U.S. loco market demand," Inch said.GE is targeting $20 billion worth of asset sales, including the transportation unit that makes locomotives, as it looks to improve cash flow and shrink its portfolio of businesses.Shares of GE fell 0.9% to 14.51 on the stock market today, slashing losses as the White House said Trump tariffs may exempt Canada and Mexico. Inch has a price target of 13 on GE stock and a sell rating, but the stock is still hanging on to a weekly gain after a longtime GE analyst said Monday he saw material upside potential over the near and medium term.Dow Jones peers United Technologies (UTX) and 3M (MMM) fell 0.5% and rose 0.85%, respectively. Honeywell (HON) gained 0.7% and Siemens (SIEGY) added 0.4%.Use IBD's MarketSmith For Free Until March 11

Start NowFor GE, rising metal costs under the proposed 25% tariff on steel imports and 10% tariff on aluminum imports would come at a challenging time. It already confronts depressed power-generation markets across the globe that have created significant earnings and cash pressures.Trump's top economic advisor Gary Cohn quit the White House Tuesday in the wake of tensions over the tariff issue, reports said.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:If General Electric Breaks Up, Should You Break Up With GE's Stock?How To Invest: Learn To Use The 50-Day Moving AverageBlockchain Expands Beyond Bitcoin To Amazon, Nvidia, AlibabaHere Are 10 Chip Stocks Breaking Out, Hitting Highs Or Setting UpGeneral Electric: 5 Reasons Why The Worst Could Be Over For GE Stock

United Technologies (UTX) stock punched up on news that activist investor Bill Ackman's Pershing Square is building a stake in the manufacturing conglomerate.X Ackman told CNBC he thinks the Dow blue chip is a "great" company. The billionaire investor also said he had unwound a short position in Herbalife (HLF), a maker of nutritional supplements, after a massive short bet proved very costly.Other industrial conglomerates have come under pressure from activist hedge funds to streamline their businesses.Dan Loeb's Third Point pushed for Honeywell International (HON) to spin off its aerospace business. Honeywell eventually decided to hold on to aerospace but spin off its automotive turbochargers and home-systems units. Nelson Peltz's Trian Partners targeted General Electric (GE), pushing for cost cuts and eventually winning a board seat.UTC and fellow Dow Jones industrial giant GE are also mulling moves to split up key parts of their businesses.Shares of United Technologies rose 0.6% to close at 134.74 on the stock market today. Honeywell gave up 1.8% amid news of Amazon's push into the home security market with its Ring acquisition. GE lost 2.7%, resuming its decline after Monday's news of a Justice Department probe into its legacy subprime mortgage business. Herbalife surged 6.3%.Get IBD's Market Prep And Tech Report Newsletters — For Free!United Technologies CEO Gregory Hayes said last week that a potential breakup of the company, which makes everything from jet engines to Carrier air conditioners and Otis elevators, is under consideration."Is United Technologies a more valuable property together or is UTC better off in three separate businesses? That's the question for the board," Hayes said at an industrials conference in Miami on Feb. 21. "That's the question we continue to study."YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:If General Electric Breaks Up, Should You Break Up With GE's Stock?2018 Stock Market Forecasts: Read The Predictions For Top Stocks And IndustriesHow To Invest In The Stock Market: Start With A Simple RoutineGrubhub Price Target Raised On Optimism Over Yum Brands DealTaco Bell Parent Yum Brands Serves Mixed Earnings, Teams Up With GrubhubWhich Companies Are Now Outperforming 95% Of All Stocks?

Amazon's (AMZN) Ring acquisition hit ADT (ADT) and Johnson Controls (JCI)  Wednesday — but the home systems unit that Honeywell (HON) is looking to spin off may become the next Jeff Bezos target.X A day after Amazon purchased Ring, analysts on Wall Street warned that the online giant's push into home security is an unwelcome development for companies that operate in the hotly contested market for smart home security products."Security has already been an underperforming sector due to a shift away from professional installers and an influx of new competitors," Jeff Sprague of Vertical Research Partners wrote in a note to clients.Sprague sees residential security most under pressure, where lead players such as ADT face stiff competition from DIY and self-monitoring systems. Ring's smart doorbell streams audio and visuals to smartphones, for example.Johnson Controls' security products business, Honeywell's home product portfolio and United Technologies' (UTX) safety and security unit likely face the most near-term risk, he added.Honeywell said in October it's planning to spin off two divisions including Homes by the end of 2018. Sprague said Homes could become an Amazon target."The announcement that Amazon is acquiring the doorbell video security company Ring probably does not help the sentiment for companies competing in the increasingly contested smart home security market," RBC Capital Markets analyst Deane Dray wrote after Honeywell's investor event. He has a sector-perform rating and 158 price target on Honeywell stock.Shares of ADT, which went public in January, plunged 9% to 10.56 on the stock market today, after diving 4.5% Tuesday. General Electric (GE) seeks to hive off a part of its industrial gas engine business in a move that could be an opening salvo in a more far-reaching breakup of the industrial conglomerate.X GE's divestiture of the unit, which makes the Jenbacher and Waukesha gas engines, would help management deliver on its promise to right-size its struggling core power division. It could bring inasmuch as $2 billion, Reuters reported Friday. The gas engines generate 100 kW to 10 MW of power and heat for industries in more than 100 countries across the globe. GE has manufactured gas engines for more than 80 years.GE reportedly has hired Citigroup (C) to prepare a sale process for the industrial gas business. Neither GE nor Citigroup offered a comment to Reuters.Shares of GE lost 2.1% to 17.74 on the stock market today. The Dow component's stock has halved in value over the past year and sits at its lowest level in more than six years. Dow peers United Technologies (UTX) and 3M (MMM) lost 2.2% and 0.7%, respectively. Honeywell (HON) rose 0.2% and Siemens (SIEGY) gave up 0.35%.Get IBD's Market Prep And Tech Report Newsletters — For Free!GE powers more than 30% of the world's electricity, but sales of power plants and gas turbines fell sharply last year. In Q4, power revenue fell 15% to $9.4 billion and profits plunged 88% to $260 million. In November, the industrial giant said gas power generation remains a key market but admitted to poor planning and operational execution, even as that market became more competitive and overcapacity issues ballooned.GE was hard hit by the acquisition of French multinational Alstom's power and grid businesses for $10.1 billion in 2015. It placed that bet as global markets for gas power grew sluggish, critics say, and made too many concessions to secure the deal. GE anticipated $3 billion in cost synergies and a strong return from the deal, but said in November the transaction was performing below expectations.CEO John Flannery said at the time that he expects it will take one to two years to fix GE Power. In December, GE announced plans to slash 12,000 jobs from its power unit as part of a broader effort to cut $3.5 billion in costs by the end of 2018. Disruptions in the power market are driving significantly lower volumes in products and services, GE Power CEO Russell Stokes said.In January, Flannery signaled he was open to a more far-reaching breakup of the company and floated the idea of spinning off or even selling GE's power, health care and aviation mainstays.Meanwhile, the company is being probed by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for issues tied to a legacy long-term-care insurance business. It is selling parts of its overseas lighting business to a company a former executive Joerg Bauer.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:If General Electric Breaks Up, Should You Break Up With GE's Stock?2018 Stock Market Forecasts: Read The Predictions For Top Stocks And IndustriesHow To Invest In The Stock Market: Start With A Simple Routine

General Electric (GE) shares turned lower Monday afternoon as a widely followed Wall Street analyst turned more bearish on the stock.X Steve Tusa of JPMorgan said that he sees "an expedited evolution of outcomes at GE" given continued underperformance, challenging fundamentals, revelations about the cash hole in its financial  business, and lack of signs of a turnaround.Tusa noted recent management comments on evaluating the conglomerate's vast portfolio of businesses. But he sees "more urgency in the situation" given the recent moves in GE bonds and, he added, a growing realization that, even if cash improves, the balance sheet does not offer many options for future growth."In other words, it's either a steady grind in uncertain markets, with risk that things get more extreme in more volatile capital markets, or it's a change in structure to try and de-risk, and simplify the portfolio to grow it in a more focused way in the future, and we see a bit of a mix," Tusa wrote in a Feb. 12 note to clients.A low-growth portfolio "with weak free cash flow and too much leverage" raises the question of whether an equity raise is possible, Tusa added. Honeywell (HON) and Siemens (SIEGY) climbed 1.1% and 1.5%, respectively.IBD'S TAKE: GE stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 2 out of a best-possible 99. Computer networking equipment maker Netgear (NTGR) plunged on plans to spin off its fast-growing Arlo security-camera business and hold an initial public offering for shares in the firm.San Jose, Calif.-based Netgear announced the move late Tuesday along with its fourth-quarter earnings report, which beat expectations on the bottom line, but missed views on sales.Netgear shares tumbled more than 15% to close at 57.05 on the stock market today. Netgear rose 2% to 67.40 on Tuesday.Netgear expects the IPO of its Arlo Technologies unit to be completed in the second half of 2018. Netgear expects Arlo to issue less than 20% of its common stock in the IPO, with Netgear retaining the remaining interest. Following the IPO, Netgear intends to distribute the shares it holds in Arlo to Netgear shareholders.Netgear says its Arlo devices are the top-selling, do-it-yourself home security cameras in North American retail. Arlo competes with device makers like Canary, Ring, Amazon's (AMZN) Blink and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Nest, as well as smart-home companies like Alarm.com (ALRM), Honeywell (HON) and Vivint.Global Equities Research analyst Trip Chowdhry said Arlo could easily be valued at $3.5 billion, topping the price Alphabet's Google paid for Nest. Google bought Nest Labs in January 2014 for $3.2 billion. Nest makes smart thermostats, smoke detectors, security cameras and other devices.Arlo has been growing at 100% year over year for each of the past three years, Chowdhry said."Netgear Arlo should continue to grow over 50% on a revenue base of about $400 million," he said in a report to clients Wednesday. "Conservatively, if we project a revenue growth rate of 50% for fiscal 2018, it gives (Arlo) revenue of about $575 million in fiscal 2018. Less than 1% of U.S. households own an Arlo, hence there is huge runway ahead for Arlo."IBD'S TAKE: Netgear stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 90 out of a best-possible 99. For more analysis on Netgear, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Arlo will appeal to growth investors, while Netgear will appeal to value investors, Chowdhry said.At the end of 2017, Arlo had 1.7 million users. Arlo has shipped over 6.5 million Arlo cameras, so each registered user buys three to four Arlo cameras, Chowdhry said. Arlo also is branching out into security lights and other products, he said.Arlo generated sales of $128.5 million in the fourth quarter and $378.4 million in 2017, Netgear reported Tuesday.Netgear reported adjusted earnings per share of 71 cents in the December quarter, down 19% year over year, but topping the consensus estimate of 66 cents, according to Zacks Investment Research. Sales rose 8% to $397.1 million, but lagged views for $401 million, Zacks said.For the current quarter, Netgear guided to sales of $330 million to $345 million. It did not give a target for earnings per share. Wall Street was modeling for Netgear to earn 61 cents a share, down 5% year over year, on sales of $348 million, up 7%.RELATED:Netgear Stock Continues Winning Streak, Gets Price-Target HikeNetgear Stock Jumps On Strong CES 2018 ShowingCamera Makers Converge At CES To Combat 'Porch Pirates'

The SEC probe into how General Electric (GE) records revenue for servicing industrial equipment raises significant risks for the troubled industrial giant, according to a Wall Street analyst.X GE disclosed during its Jan. 24 quarterly report that it is being investigated by Wall Street's government watchdog. Financial regulators are looking into both what led the company to take a worse-than-feared $6.2 billion charge to its insurance reserves, as well as whether its accounting and controls for long-term service agreements (LTSAs) may have been lacking in any way.The service agreements — a major part of what GE calls "contract assets" — are troubling to John Inch of Deutsche Bank. They have become bigger drivers of GE's slowing profits, even though they are drawn in large part from GE's severely challenged power business, he wrote in a Jan. 29 analyst note."LTSAs potentially comprised 22% of GE's earnings in 2017 — a sizable step-up from 16% in 2016 despite the 2017 collapse of the Power business," he noted.That discrepancy highlights issues tied to the value of GE's contract assets. One is that GE often books revenue before it actually gets paid by customers. Another is that the ongoing downturn in the power market heightens the risk that GE may have to revise down the value of its contract assets, Inch said."If GE were required to revise down the value of its contract assets (which are based on internal company assumptions), this would result in negative drag to the company's book value — coming at a time of rapidly rising GE Industrial debt," Inch added. Ultimately, a potential write-down could hurt Wall Street's consensus 2018 EPS guidance of $1 for GE, pushing its share price even lower, he said.Shares of GE slipped 2% to 15.95 stock market today, closing below 16 for the first time since Dec. 1, 2011. Dow industrial peers 3M (MMM) and United Technologies (UTX) posted losses of 1.75% and 0.1%, respectively, while Siemens (SIEGY) was flat and Honeywell (HON) gave up 1.5%.IBD'S TAKE: With thousands of publicly traded companies to choose from, how can you quickly find the best stocks to buy right now? A good starting point is to regularly review screens that highlight the top-rated equities.GE's contract assets have grown steadily in recent years to roughly $25 billion in 2016, and GE expects that figure to increase to roughly $30 billion in 2018.In recent notes, analysts besides Inch addressed the SEC inquiry into the Boston-based company's contract asset accounting and insurance processes.Jeff Sprague of Vertical Research suggested Jan. 24 that GE's accounting may have been too aggressive, saying more charges or write-downs are possible before GE files its annual 10-K report. Steve Tusa of JPMorgan said Jan. 26 that the probe lends support to concerns around potential shareholder lawsuits.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:How To Choose The Best Online Stock Brokers: Start HereBest Stocks To Buy And WatchHow To Invest In The Stock Market Using A Simple Routine

General Electric (GE), an icon of American industry and the last remaining component of the original Dow Jones industrial average, now presents investors with a dilemma. At the brink of a potential breakup of the 126-year-old conglomerate, does the widely followed GE stock offer a transformational investment opportunity — or a dead end?X After years of attempts to remake the sprawling company, GE watchers aren't sure. Some say a GE breakup could unleash robust returns, but others see nothing but more damage to its already diminished value.After outlining a major slim-down in November, new GE CEO John Flannery is now open to a breakup, he revealed Jan. 16, and a major activist investor has reportedly pushed for it. But even breakup proponents say there's no quick fix for GE's problems. Indeed, key roadblocks, legal and otherwise, could make sticking together a better bet than a breakup for holders of GE stock."GE cannot whittle down to three separate entities" in power, aviation and health care, said Deutsche Bank analyst John Inch. "Trust me, if it could, it would."Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe breakup question comes as investors look for some upside to the beleaguered GE share price, which is at the lowest since December 2011. The company's status as an income stock play, a key reason to hold GE stock, was severely damaged after it halved its quarterly dividend to 12 cents a share in November. (The falling stock price, though, raises GE's dividend yield.)IBD'S TAKE: Investing for income alone can be risky if you chase stocks just because of their high dividend yields. Learn how to buy the best dividend stocks that combine yields with earnings growth and a solid share price trend. News of a potential breakup follows a disastrous 2017 for GE stock, which tanked 45% while the Dow Jones industrial average soared 25% and fellow Dow industrials 3M (MMM) and United Technologies (UTX) jumped a respective 32% and 16%. GE's low price could even threaten its status as a Dow component. Other industrial conglomerates like Siemens (SIEGY) and Honeywell (HON), which also have also taken steps to slim down recently, saw hefty 2017 gains too.But you can't blame GE for not trying. The company is vastly different from what it was a decade ago. It has shed its stake in NBC Universal and most of one-time profit driver GE Capital, as well as its iconic lighting and appliance businesses. Former CEO Jeff Immelt sought to refocus GE on its industrial core and rebrand it as a "digital industrial" company, touting its efforts in software and the cloud.But that failed to arrest the decline of GE stock. Immelt stepped down as CEO in June after a 16-year tenure, and General Electric's longtime chief financial officer left in October. Soon after taking over as CEO, Flannery laid out plans in November to unload another $20 billion in assets and focus on the company's aviation, health care and power segments, which together account for most of GE's industrial revenue and profits.Yet the plan pleased almost no one, neither analysts seeking a radical restructuring of its vast asset portfolio nor investors looking for a clear path back to growth. It also left lingering concerns over the flagship power segment, which sells gas turbines and other utility equipment, where plunging profits led to 12,000 GE job cuts in December. Analysts caution that the power market is in the early stages of an extended downturn.The sale of other, smaller businesses had been telegraphed by GE, so Flannery's November announcement produced little sense of a bold vision. Then came the Jan. 16 bombshell that GE was on the hook for $11 billion in charges from its long-term care insurance portfolio and new U.S. tax laws. Management acknowledged more drastic moves might be needed. GE stock ended last week with a 13% loss, marking its worst week since 2009.GE shares fell a fraction Monday ahead of the company's fourth-quarter earnings report on Wednesday. Some analysts expect GE to slash 2018 earnings guidance again."We are looking aggressively at the best structure or structures for our portfolio to maximize the potential of our businesses," Flannery said on a conference call. A review "could result in many, many different permutations, including separately traded assets really in any one of our units, if that's what made sense."For now, GE says everything is on the table, include outright sales and spinoffs. Flannery also floated the idea of staged exits, akin to the merger of GE's oil and gas division into Baker Hughes last July to form Baker Hughes a GE Company (BHGE).Other equity analysts look on GE more favorably. The conglomerate is now an asset story, and GE's well-established aerospace and health care segments would make exceptional stand-alone businesses, Scott Davis of Melius Research told IBD. Those two units alone are worth more than the entire market cap of GE, he says, while accounting for less than 40% of GE's revenue.GE Aviation is "one of the best aerospace assets out there," Davis wrote in a December sum-of-the-parts analysis. He sees significant long-term value in the Leap engine and says aviation should enjoy strong services demand in the next two to three years.Here's What Fidelity Stock-Picker Will Danoff Likes Now – And What He Says About GEAnd General Electric could easily spin off its health care assets to "unlock value" in GE stock, similar to Siemens' upcoming IPO of its Healthineers unit, he adds.While Davis calls GE's power business severely challenged due to the rise of renewable energy, he believes it is fixable, with room for positive surprises down the road.Besides, Davis notes, the shareholder bases for GE's core businesses are completely different. For example, power holds appeal as a dividend payer and aviation as a secular growth engine.More immediately, he says Flannery should focus on cutting costs. That includes everything from general corporate expenses to its global research centers and its Predix software platform for the industrial Internet of Things. Many of these he describes as ex-CEO Immelt's "very expensive investments that have just not panned out."Since GE's Jan. 16 investor update, Davis has even more conviction in a GE breakup scenario."The recent news helps confirm the fact that GE is too complex in its current form," he said. "The conglomerate structure incentivizes wasteful and duplicative spending, while stifling the true earnings power of the underlying businesses."But GE may not be able to take bold action without a feat of financial wizardry. What remains of GE Capital is saddled with $97.5 billion in debt, and the company is on the hook for more than $31 billion in underfunded pension liabilities, Deutsche Bank's Inch said in a Jan. 17 note to clients. GE is unlikely to separate aviation, power and health care into three stand-alone companies, especially since its industrial businesses backstop GE Capital's debt, he argues."A separation of GE could carry serious ramifications in the bond market on which GE continues to heavily rely" to fund the pension plan and operations, including the risk of litigation from GE Capital bondholders, he wrote.GE bonds also risk a rapid debt downgrade if General Electric gets rid of cash-generating businesses, which it can ill afford as a company on the hook for billions in pension obligations, he said in an interview.Other risks to GE stock loom. Inch cited billions in potential liability tied to the long-term-care insurance business, an "inexplicably low" tax rate that is almost certain to rise over time, a "completely ineffective board" that failed its duty to provide oversight and the "very large, looming threat" of class-action lawsuits from shareholders who may now feel misled.Before November, "the company was adamant everything was great, the dividend was safe and secure," said Inch. "I don't see how a company so large sees its earnings and dividends collapse. Somebody in the government, the SEC specifically, should be looking at what happened to get us to this point."A GE spokeswoman said the company "continues to work constructively with (government) agents as issues like that come up." GE has set up a new board committee focused on capital allocation as it explores "all options" for its structure and portfolio, and is working through the legal and IP ramifications as part of its rigorous review, she added.For others, the math doesn't support the case for a GE breakup. A sum-of-the-parts analysis by Cowen's Gautam Khanna found GE's breakup value was 11-15 a share, below the current GE stock price near 16, after factoring in the underfunded pension and other debt-like items."This implies that investors are currently ascribing a 'conglomerate premium' to GE's portfolio," Khanna said. In other words, asset sales are unlikely to add value, and a full GE breakup could even destroy value.And that doesn't account for operational synergies among the businesses that would be lost in a breakup of General Electric, he adds.Morningstar equity analyst Barbara Noverini also points out that innovations in one GE unit can provide solutions for another. For example, a subsea drilling platform in the oil and gas segment may draw from three other units: turbines from the power segment, distribution networks from energy management and imaging technology created in the health care segment.GE's complicated portfolio makes restructuring likely to be a multiyear slog, depressing earnings growth in the near term, she says. And in the GE dividend cut, the second in a decade, she sees "a stark reminder that even great portfolios can suffer under the weight of poor capital allocation."CFRA analyst Jim Corridore, too, points to synergies among General Electric's core units as a reason why a complete GE breakup is unlikely. The "core R&D" needed to make a gas turbine or an aircraft engine is basically the same, he says. Additive manufacturing technologies, or 3D printing, also connect its diverse business."When you build a conglomerate, you build it for a reason," he told IBD. "To break (conglomerates) up just because shareholders don't like the direction of the stock, that's no way to run a business."YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:2018 Stock Market Forecasts: Read The Predictions For Top Stocks And IndustriesHow Did This Biotech Stock Become A Dividend Leader?This Top-Performing Dow Titan Is Reaping The Benefits of RestructuringAI In Business: What The Future HoldsHow To Invest In The Stock Market: Start With A Simple Routine

General Electric (GE) may have been nudged by a major shareholder to consider a breakup, which the industrial giant signaled Tuesday is an option while announcing a multibillion-dollar hit from a legacy long-term-care insurance business.X Activist investor Nelson Peltz's Trian Fund Management is pushing the 125-year old industrial giant to explore possible sales or spin-outs of its sprawling businesses — including those in the core health and power segments, The New York Post said late Tuesday citing unnamed sources.Trian's founding partner Ed Garden, who also serves on the GE board, reportedly has been meeting with GE chief John Flannery recently. Trian declined to comment to the Post."We are looking aggressively at the best structure or structures for our portfolio to maximize the potential of our businesses," Flannery said Tuesday in a call with analysts. He added "separately traded assets really in any one of our units" was an option. As recently as November, GE had said it would keep its key power, aviation and health care businesses even as it looks to exit several others.Trian has seen its stake in the Dow stock drastically dwindle in value since first making a hefty $2.5 billion investment in 2015, which the Post suggested came at the behest of former CEO Jeff Immelt. Trian bought GE at $26 per share. GE shares dived 4.7% to 17.35 on the stock market today, surrendering the last of their 2018 gains. GE hit 17.26 intraday,  just above a six-year low of 17.25 from Dec. 28.Among GE's industrial conglomerate peers, Siemens (SIEGY) and Honeywell (HON), which are also slimming down portfolios, were up 3 cents and 0.3%, respectively. Fellow Dow member United Technologies (UTX), which is acquiring Rockwell Collins (COL), edged up 0.3%.IBD'S TAKE: This Dow giant hit a buy zone on its 2018 outlook. As long as the current "confirmed uptrend" — the equivalent of a green light — stays in place, leading stocks breaking above a buy point are more likely than not to have the wind at their backs. Here's a good place to start looking for stocks that may be poised to move higher.Trian delivered a 4% return in 2017, lower than most of its hedge-fund peers, the Post said, attributing that performance to GE.The firm was seen to back the exit of Immelt and pushed for deeper restructuring, but Garden voiced support for Flannery while gaining a board seat late last year.Trian both demands change at companies and collaborates behind the scenes with management to turn troubled businesses around.GE did not respond to an IBD request for comment on the Post story.MORE YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Chip-Gear Stocks Rock On These 2 Upbeat Earnings ReportsStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksHow To Find The Best Stocks Before They Break Out

General Electric (GE) is leaning toward a breakup, with a decision expected as soon as this spring, sources told CNBC Tuesday.X The report followed an announcement from the industrial giant earlier in the day that it would take a $6.2 billion Q4 charge on its legacy reinsurance business as well as comments from CEO John Flannery that the charge and results from the past several years "only further my belief that we need to continue to move with purpose to reshape GE.""We are looking aggressively at the best structure or structures for our portfolio to maximize the potential of our businesses," he said on a conference call, according to Bloomberg. A review "could result in many, many different permutations, including separately traded assets really in any one of our units, if that's what made sense."GE has already announced plans to shed $20 billion in assets and narrow its scope to just three businesses: aviation, power systems and health care, which together account for majority of GE's industrial revenue and profits.But that plan was widely panned after its was unveiled in November and failed to halt the stock's free fall, which was worsened by GE's halving of its dividend to conserve capital.GE shares were down 3.3% at 18.14 on the stock market today, falling back below their 50-day moving average after a two-week rally. Siemens (SIEGY) and Honeywell (HON), which have also taken steps to slim down recently, were up 0.7% and down 0.7%, respectively. United Technologies (UTX), which is acquiring Rockwell Collins (COL), lost 1.9%.IBD'S TAKE: This Dow giant just hit a buy zone on its 2018 outlook. As long as the current "confirmed uptrend" — the equivalent of a green light — stays in place, leading stocks breaking above a buy point are more likely than not to have the wind at their backs. Here's a good place to start looking for stocks that may be poised to move higher.GE also announced Tuesday that its GE Capital unit expects to make statutory reserve contributions, to fill a shortfall in the insurance portfolio, of about $15 billion over seven years. It will contribute about $3 billion in the first quarter of 2018 and roughly $2 billion each following year through 2024. To fund that, GE Capital will suspend dividends to GE for the foreseeable future.GE said the review and reserve testing, conducted with the help of outside experts, were tied to long-term-care policies reinsured by GE Capital's runoff insurance business, North American Life & Health. The moves will help restore GE Capital ratios to appropriate levels, he added, noting that the unit plays a key role in helping finance GE's portfolio of industrial products."At a time when we are moving forward as a company, a charge of this magnitude from a legacy insurance portfolio in runoff for more than a decade is deeply disappointing," Flannery, who assumed the role of chief executive in August, said.Deutsche Bank research analyst John Inch flagged GE insurance risks in a Jan. 5 note. He noted that GE spun off Genworth, a big player in traditional long-term-care insurance, in May 2004, but the company has struggled with negative claims tied to its long-term-care portfolio since at least 2014."Perhaps surprising to many, GE retained substantial long-term-care insurance policies that are now expected to cost the company billions of dollars," he wrote. In light of GE's cash crunch, he wondered if GE's insurance woes offer a clue as to why the company is pursuing the divestitures of its rail and prospectively Baker Hughes (BHGE) units "at a potentially less than optimal time" from a cyclical perspective.MORE YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:These 5 Top Tech Stocks Are Near Buys With Strong RS LinesStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksHow To Find The Best Stocks Before They Break Out

LAS VEGAS — The increase in package deliveries from the growth of e-commerce has brought with it the new problem of "porch pirates" — thieves who brazenly steal parcels right off people's front porches.X Now, however, the consumer electronics industry has a solution in security cameras that can help catch criminals and even prevent thefts in progress.Numerous companies, large and small, are at the massive CES consumer technology conference this week showing off their security systems. They range from specialists like Ring and Canary to smart-home experts like Alarm.com (ALRM) and Vivint. Other major players include networking gear maker Netgear (NTGR) and home technologies firm Honeywell (HON).Table stakes for home security cams today are cloud storage of video and smartphone alerts to activity and the ability to scare away crooks with sirens or by talking to them through two-way audio, plus the ability to call the police.In December, e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN) bought Blink, a maker of smart doorbell and porch cameras, adding to Amazon's line of connected home products that includes Echo smart speakers and Fire TV streaming devices.Videos during the holiday season of porch pirates raised awareness of the need for outdoor security cameras, said Don Shulsinger, vice president of sales and marketing for Blink."We have received a lot of videos of package thefts caught on camera," he said. "It's a big problem for consumers and we see it as a tremendous opportunity."Blink cameras start at $99 and include free cloud storage.A new trend in the category is the ability for users of home security cameras to share videos of suspicious activity, speeding cars and other occurrences with their neighbors. Ring has the capability in its smartphone app now and Vivint is launching an app called Streety in March.Local television news stations often air videos of burglars and thieves captured on home security cams and the videos have been instrumental in arrests of suspects, Shulsinger said.

General Electric (GE) is no longer a sell, in the view of Deutsche Bank, which resumed coverage of GE stock with a hold rating."Management is taking bold actions to unlock value, and we do acknowledge arbitrage opportunity," analyst Nicole DeBlase of Deutsche Bank wrote in a note released late Wednesday.She added: "On a near term basis, some risk (arbitrage) investors might want to take advantage of a gap vs. our $16 base case sum of the parts valuation, following recent portfolio change announcements. However, fundamental investors will likely continue to struggle with the company's Power business, where we see little scope for medium-term recovery, and we believe consensus is already giving credit for early traction on cost cutting initiatives."DeBlase, who has a 15 price target, rated the stock a hold given "modest upside" potential.Deutsche Bank suspended coverage on March 29. But before that, a different Deutsche Bank analyst and longtime GE bear correctly predicted both GE's dividend cut and booting from the Dow Jones industrial average.The analyst warned in January that the Boston-based conglomerate might exit the Dow blue-chip index, citing "earnings and cash pressure, tough global power generation markets, aggressive downsizing, shrinking its portfolio, management shake-up and SEC investigations." That prediction was realized in June.In May 2017, Deutsche Bank warned GE's worsening cash flow could imperil shareholder returns. Roughly six months later, the company halved both its profit outlook and its prized dividend.The stock's decline accelerated, with the yield rising to a current 3.4%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseGeneral Electric finished flat at 13.99 on the stock market today but has nearly halved over the past year. GE stock continues to test its 50-day moving average within a monthslong consolidation. As trade war fears eased, GE's industrial conglomerate peers rallied after broad losses Wednesday. United Technologies (UTX) gained 2% and 3M (MMM) edged up 0.8%. Siemens (SIEGY) eked out a 1% gain and Honeywell (HON) rallied 2.3%.The Boston-based company announced in June, after a yearlong strategic portfolio review, that "GE of the future" will focus on power, aviation and renewable energy, after divesting several other businesses.DeBlase sees "clear opportunity for arbitrage investors as the company moves closer to completing its Transportation merger and Healthcare separation." But she called the trajectory of GE's remaining businesses "uninspiring," with "no V-shaped recovery in sight," owing in large part to a severely challenged power market.She also noted GE is disposing off its strongest units in terms of free cash flow conversion – health care, transportation and lighting. "GE RemainCo will be left with far weaker FCF conversion than the various disposals," she said.The aviation unit, which some analysts call the crown jewel in a vast portfolio, is set to benefit as Indian carrier Vistara plans massive expansion and eyes overseas growth.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:If General Electric Breaks Up, Should You Break Up With GE's Stock?IBD Stock Of The DayBest Growth Stocks To Buy And Watch: See Updates To IBD Stock ListsStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stock

Siemens (SIEGY) and Alibaba (BABA) are partnering to build the industrial Internet of Things in China. That comes weeks after General Electric (GE) affirmed it will continue to invest in digital technologies while shrinking expenditures elsewhere.The German industrial giant will make its MindSphere operating system available on Alibaba's cloud-computing platform for customers in mainland China, the companies jointly announced Monday.Siemens' MindSphere connects industrial machines and factories via the cloud. It's akin to GE's Predix, which outfits equipment with data-collecting sensors and then analyzes the resulting information using industrial software to improve performance and cut costs.The Alibaba pact "is a landmark deal for bringing Industrie 4.0 solutions to China as the world's powerhouse of manufacturing," Joe Kaeser, Siemens president and CEO, said in a statement.Shares of Siemens rallied 0.9% to 68.20 on the stock market today, while Alibaba fell 0.6%.GE punched up 1.7% to recover the 50-day moving average. GE stock is basing as some market watchers see signs of a bottom and call the stock a long-term buy. United Technologies (UTX), 3M (MMM) and Honeywell (HON) rose 1% or more.Under the memorandum of understanding signed Monday in Berlin, the Siemens and Alibaba digital partnership starts immediately. They hope to make MindSphere available on Alibaba Cloud, the e-commerce giant's cloud-computing unit, next year.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseMany industrial conglomerates are trying to integrate cutting-edge technologies into their traditional businesses.Their investments in digital technology come as other parts of their vast operations struggle. Recently, both Siemens and GE slashed thousands of jobs as orders for power-plant equipment crumpled.Siemens has merged or spun off assets in wind, rail and health care. Last month, GE announced it will shed its health care and oil-and-gas businesses to focus on power, aviation and renewable energy.However, GE reiterated its commitment to digital investments. The company said it will "invest for the future and lead in innovative technologies like additive manufacturing and digital to lead the next wave of industrial productivity."Last year, reports arose that GE might sell a Predix stake after returns fell short of expectations.The Boston-based company was said to expect $12 billion in digital revenue in 2020, down from $15 billion earlier.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:If General Electric Breaks Up, Should You Break Up With GE's Stock?How GE Could Become The Apple Of The Industrial InternetDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And Analysis

Siemens (SIEGY) may ax thousands of workers ahead of the holiday season, becoming the latest conglomerate after General Electric (GE) and Honeywell (HON) to slash costs and restructure a sprawling portfolio in the face of tepid growth.XThe job cuts and redundancies will affect two of the German company's units — power-and-gas and process industries — Bloomberg reported Thursday, citing unidentified sources. Official word of the action, perhaps the biggest since 4,500 jobs were slashed in May 2015, could come in early November.Since taking over in August 2013, Siemens CEO Joe Kaeser has pared back several businesses to focus on the company's industrial core. The segments that are under review or have already been shed include lighting, health care, wind turbines and mobility.That is similar to moves stateside from GE, which saw significant restructuring under former chief Jeff Immelt and has kept on that path under his successor. New CEO John Flannery also reportedly plans aggressive job cuts to cut spending and boost profits. Those measures come as GE stock has plunged nearly 29% year to date.Meanwhile, Honeywell cut thousands of jobs last year as it restructured the company and recently announced plans to spin off two non-core businesses.Shares of Siemens fell 0.4% to 69.58 Thursday as they form a cup-with-handle base with a 71.39 buy point.GE spiked 2% to 23.58 on the stock market today, as investors digested news that it will partner with Apple (AAPL) on mobile apps for factory workers.Honeywell inched up 0.1% to 143.64, with the stock in buying range from a breakout past 140.31.IBD'S TAKE: Market-leading stocks usually boast an RS Rating of 80 or higher. This IBD screen helps you identify top growth stocks with superior price performance relative to the S&P 500.Siemens, like GE and Honeywell, has labored under lackluster sales and EPS growth rates over the past three years.Like its U.S. rivals, Siemens is adding software-focused solutions to legacy equipment businesses in the hope of growing profits and meeting future industrial needs.Its digital factory division, for example, helps to automate factory floors and to network machinery via the cloud.GE and Honeywell report third-quarter results Friday.RELATED:These 2 Dow Giants Are Teaming Up On The Industrial Internet Of ThingsDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisGE's Expected Q3 Profit Surge May Be Overshadowed By Dividend Fears

General Electric (GE) inked a multibillion deal with Chinese companies while industrial peers Caterpillar (CAT), Honeywell (HON), DowDuPont (DWDP), General Motors (GM) and Ford Motor (F) also scored during President Trump's state visit to China.XThey were part of a $250 billion haul for U.S. companies, but skeptics noted many feature little of substance and don't boost U.S. access to China that much.Most of Thursday's agreements are nonbinding MOU's and could take years to produce results, Bloomberg said. And an announcement from Boeing (BA) for a 300-plane order was also largely a rehash of earlier deals reached several years ago, raising questions about how much of the deal making was showmanship given that Trump has long pilloried the U.S. trade deficit with China.GE, however, did secure three new orders: $1.4 billion for GEnx-1B engines from Juneyao Airlines; $1.1 billion for 80 Leap-1B engines from ICBC Leasing; and roughly $1 billion for gas turbines and other machinery from China Datang GroupIBD'S TAKE: With thousands of publicly traded companies to choose from, how can you quickly find the best stocks to buy right now? CEO John Flannery is set to offer his turnaround strategy to shareholders Monday.Caterpillar sank 1.4% and DowDuPont dipped 0.8% Thursday, while Honeywell lost 1%. General Electric (GE) is a leaner, meaner industrial machine under new leadership, but has it been strengthening its free cash flow? Investors may find out when GE reports Friday.XAt the heart of anxiety about GE's industrial FCF (free cash flow) is the dividend that springs forth from it. GE currently pays an annualized dividend of 96 cents, translating to a tasty 4.1% yield. That has made this Dow component a favorite blue chip for income investors.But some analysts have warned of a potential dividend cut as GE prepares to report earnings amid major turnover in its corporate leadership.New CEO John Flannery has slashed expenses and trimmed the portfolio since assuming the reins on Aug. 1, though the effect on FCF going forward isn't clear yet. Next month, he is expected to unveil the results of a strategic review that calls for "thousands of corporate-level job cuts and scaling back of GE's global structure," including the closure of three research centers, according to the Wall Street Journal.Analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research see EPS increasing 56% to 50 cents as revenue climbs 9% to $31.92 billion.Organic revenue and industrial orders are two key closely watched metrics. GE must increase attachment rates on service contracts, which can underpin sustained growth in organic revenue, writes Morningstar analyst Barbara Noverini.The industrial giant's profit target of $2 per share for next year is another key issue to watch. Analysts who cover GE, as well as GE management, are turning cautious about its ability to achieve that goal. The company could address its forecast Friday or reserve the topic for Flannery's update to investors on Nov. 13.Shares of GE slipped 0.3% to 23.12 on the stock market today, after pegging a two-year-plus low of 22.83 last week. The stock has plunged more than 25% so far this year.IBD'S TAKE: As earnings season heats up, here's a list of Dow and other stocks near buy points to watch ahead of third-quarter results.Meanwhile, fellow industrial giant Honeywell (HON) reports the same day, while Dover (DOV) precedes its larger peers with a report Thursday.Analysts see Honeywell's EPS growing 4% to $1.74 on a 1.6% rise in revenue to $9.96 billion.The company recently said it will spin off its automotive turbocharger business as well as its home HVAC, fire and security business, following a portfolio review. It kept its aerospace business, which hedge fund Third Point has targeted for divestiture.Analysts expect Dover's EPS to jump 28% to $1.11 on a 16% increase in revenue to $1.98 billion.As with Honeywell, progress on efforts to streamline a diverse portfolio will be closely watched. Dover is considering a sale, spinoff or merger of its upstream energy businesses, known as Wellsite.Honeywell shares rose 1 cent to 143.44 Wednesday and are still in buy range from their Sept. 21 breakout. Dover fell 0.5% to 93.57.RELATED:Why GE Stock May Get Worse Instead Of Better As Leadership Turns OverDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisGE Shakes Up Top Execs While More Perks Fall To Cost-Cutting Drive
