General Electric (GE) on Wednesday announced more business and executive changes, spurring talk of a potential "brain drain" similar to what was seen at the industrial conglomerate after its last CEO switch 16 years ago.GE will roll its legacy power and energy connections businesses into one unit called GE Power. The current head of the power business, Steve Bolze, is leaving. He has been with GE for 24 years and led the takeover of Alstom's power and grid unit — the biggest industrial acquisition in GE's history.Russell Stokes, a 20-year GE veteran and the current head of the electrical connections unit, replaces him starting July 3.Bolze's departure has echoes of the exodus of senior managers after Jeff Immelt was named CEO in 2000, said analyst Deane Dray of RBC Capital Markets, noting that Bolze is believed to have been on the list of potential candidates to succeed Immelt.The 2000 transition resulted in the "immediate bitter" departure of the losing CEO contenders, such as Bob Nardelli, then-CEO of GE Power Systems, and Jim McNerney, then-head of GE Aircraft Engines, Dray said in a statement. (Nardelli went on to helm Home Depot (HD) and then Chrysler, while McNerney took over at 3M (MMM) and later Boeing (BA).)"That said, it is possible that the brain drain this time will be limited," Dray continued. "We note that the other leading candidate for the role, CFO Jeff Bornstein, was appointed vice chair of GE on Monday, supposedly in lieu of the CEO position."Shares of GE, a Dow Jones industrial average component, edged up 0.8% to 28.69 on the stock market today, closing just below its 50-day line. GE stock surged on Monday, when Immelt's retirement was announced, its largest gain of the year so far. But the stock is mired 13% below its July 2016 high.Among other industrial conglomerates, United Technologies (UTX) fell 3 cents to 120.03, just in range from a 114.54 buy point. Honeywell (HON) dipped 0.1% to 134.24, just below a 135.10 buy point.U.S.-listed shares of German rival Siemens (SIEGY) rose 0.1%.IBD'S TAKE: GE shares are having a strong June so far after three down months, but this is why GE is not a buy yet.Despite Immelt's upcoming retirement, incoming CEO John Flannery is expected to build on the strategy of infusing core units like aviation, power systems, transportation and energy with technology, which began under Immelt and has been generally praised.Still, GE's transformation into a digital-industrial company during Immelt's leadership has done little for the stock, which sits at around 28 — roughly where it was more than two years ago.GE stock has posted an annual average 5.2% gain in the past two years through Tuesday, roughly half that of the S&P 500 over the same period.RELATED:Stocks Flatten Ahead Of Fed, But Dow Etches New HighGE Signals New CEO Will Continue Software Push Started By Immelt

General Electric (GE) is staying the course on its digitally driven strategy started under outgoing CEO Jeff Immelt, as the Dow component on Tuesday unveiled a suite of Big Data tools and software that can transform how companies manage and service their machinery.At an event in Berlin, the industrial heavyweight unveiled digital products that allow utility companies, wind farms and oil drillers to analyze machine data in real time, identify leakages, enhance forecasts, increase productivity and even create new business opportunities.GE said the new offerings could help customers predict potential problems rather than merely react to them, thereby reducing costs and eliminating idle time.GE on Monday announced its first new leader in 16 years after nearly a decade of shedding its finance and media businesses and infusing core units like aviation, power systems, transportation and energy with technology.Underpinning these efforts is the company's Predix cloud-based software platform, a key initiative of Immelt that outfits industrial machinery with sensors that collect and monitor data, which can then be analyzed both on job sites and through remote servers. GE estimates the so-called industrial internet will be a $225 billion market by 2020, fueling massive gains in productivity and innovation.GE Vice Chair Beth Comstock told reporters in Germany that the company won't retreat from its software push under John Flannery, who will take over as CEO on Aug. 1."I don't know how you don't go digital as an industrial company," she said, according to Bloomberg. "John Flannery knows this firsthand. He's very aware of what's happening in other businesses. He's not in isolation."In addition to GE's traditional industrial rivals, tech giants like Oracle (ORCL), Microsoft (MSFT) and Amazon (AMZN) are eying the industrial internet as well, though GE is partnering with them too.Shares of GE closed down 1.7% at 28.45 on the stock market today, dropping back below their 50-day line and reversing an early gain. The stock surged 3.5% in massive volume Monday on news of the leadership change. Despite significant changes to GE's strategy in recent years, its stock has been stagnant for roughly two years.Among other industrial conglomerates, United Technologies (UTX) edged up 0.15% Tuesday and still in buy range, Honeywell (HON) inched up 0.85% to 134.39, closer to a 135.20 buy point, and U.S.-listed shares of German rival Siemens (SIEGY) added 0.5%.RELATED:This 'Outlier' GE Unit May Ironically Be Ripe For Sale Under New CEOWill Microsoft Cloud GE's Industrial Internet Hopes? Not So Fast5 Red Flags From This GE Warning That Sent The Stock To 15-Month LowsWhy General Electric May Miss This Key Earnings Goal Next Year

General Electric's (GE) chief executive suggested clouds hang over the company's earnings outlook for next year, saying volatility in energy commodities poses a significant challenge to core GE businesses such as oil and gas, power and transportation."Pricing is still tough" in the resources market, CEO Jeff Immelt said Wednesday at the Electrical Products Group Conference in Florida.An EPS goal of $2 for 2018 is at the high end of expectations "assuming the markets don't get better," he added.Tough equipment pricing and political volatility are additional headwinds for GE, weighing on the outlook for its industrial and health care segments, Immelt warned.His comments sent shares of GE down 1.6% to 27.83 erasing early gains on the stock market today. The stock had rebounded for the prior four sessions. On May 18, shares intraday matched their lowest level since October 2015.GE's relative strength line, which tracks the stock's performance vs. the S&P 500 index, is even worse. That RS line is at its lowest point since the early 1980s.Immelt is under pressure from an activist investor to improve performance at the industrial bellwether. Nelson Peltz of Trian Partners had reportedly pushed for Immelt's departure earlier this year, insisting the company could earn $2.33 a share next year if it met cost and sales goals. But after some discussions with Trian, GE said in March it would tailor this year's bonus program to the company's ability to meet profit targets and a new cost-cutting goal.Against that backdrop, the chief executive was eager on Wednesday to spotlight recent efforts to narrow the company's scope — actions that he pitched as stoking organic growth and cash flow."We've made more big portfolio changes over the last three years than at any time in the company's history," Immelt said. "The focus now is to wheel into execution."The company's recent deals for Baker Hughes (BHI) and French energy company Alstom are part of what Immelt described as a "much simpler, much deeper portfolio" focused on businesses with big moats.The company also has disposed off several smaller or underperforming businesses. Those changes put it on track to deliver 3%-5% organic growth, a 100 basis-points margin expansion and 80% to 90% free cash flow conversion, Immelt said.Still, GE stock is one of the worst performers on the Dow Jones industrial average so far this year, down 12% year to date. Only Verizon Communications (VZ) has fared worse, down 16%.By comparison, GE rivals such as Siemens (SIEGY), Honeywell International (HON) and United Technologies (UTX) each flourish double-digit gains year to date, with their stocks trading at or near 52-week highs.RELATED:5 Red Flags From This GE Warning That Sent The Stock To 15-Month LowsThese 2 Industrial Bellwethers Topped Earnings, 1 Hit A Buy PointDow's General Electric Spikes On Report CEO Jeffrey Immelt On 'Hot Seat' With Key InvestorDow Stock GE May Have Headed Off Activist Investor Fight With This Move

Honeywell (HON) touted its aerospace business as being "in a great position in a growing industry," amid pressure from an activist investor who argues it would perform better as a spinoff.In a presentation at the Electrical Products Group conference in Florida Tuesday, Honeywell said increasing global flight hours, new aircraft ramping up and improving worldwide defense budgets offer "further runway" for margin expansion.Honeywell's aerospace investments totaled $2.5 billion in 2016 and are expected to climb in 2017. Over 15% of Honeywell sales are channeled into aerospace research and development — two times as much as its closest rivals, the company said.However, Third Point's Dan Loeb has said the aerospace unit has been a laggard relative to industry peers and that a spinoff would boost stock valuations and increase shareholder value by more than $20 billion.Honeywell had already been conducting a strategic review of its portfolio and said Tuesday it is "modeling various scenarios," with its assessment to wrap up by this fall.Honeywell stock rose 1 cent to 131.85 in afternoon trade on the stock market today, still in buy range after clearing a 127.62 entry last month. Among other big industrials with aerospace businesses, General Electric (GE) climbed 0.35%, United Technologies (UTX) edged up 0.3%, and Rockwell Collins (COL) lost 0.1%.New leadership at Honeywell may work in Third Point's favor, according to RBC Capital Markets, which said in a note last month that "new CEOs are often more willing to rethink an organization's portfolio." Darius Adamczyk took over as Honeywell's CEO and president in April.Honeywell, which makes airplane engines and other aircraft parts, cut its full-year sales forecast in January, citing weaker demand in corporate jets amid global trepidation about the economy and less traction in defense.However, the supplier to Boeing (BA) and Airbus (EADSY) beat first-quarter earnings expectations last month. But the aerospace segment's revenue slipped 4% to $3.55 billion, while overall sales were flat at $9.49 billion.RELATED:A Honeywell Aerospace Spinoff Could Hinge On ThisActivist Investor Third Point Urges Honeywell To Spin Off Aerospace UnitDow Stock GE May Have Headed Off Activist Investor Fight With This Move

General Electric (GE) shares hit a 15-month low after receiving a downgrade to sell from hold from Deutsche Bank, which cited a range of issues for the industrial giant, including cash flow pressure to a potential leadership change."Overall, we believe GE to be overvalued given weak earnings quality and the wide gap between noncash and cash earnings," wrote Deutsche Bank analyst John Inch, who cut his price target on the company to 24 from 28.The core industrial business appears to be struggling, added Inch, who estimates that excluding GE Capital dividends and proceeds from divestitures, "GE does not appear to be generating sufficient cash flow to sustain its operations.""We believe GE's cash challenges are ultimately grounded in GE's profile as a manufacturer of 'big iron' capital goods that require high levels of investment and spending to develop and manufacture," he wrote.Inch also said GE's "weak cash flow has become worse in recent quarters," noting that it could threaten shareholder returns."While GE is going to realize cash inflow from business sales (ie, Water, Industrial Solutions) and ongoing PPE (property, plant and equipment) divestitures, the company appears to be operating relatively 'close to the line' in terms of sufficient cash generation to continue to fund such a robust dividend and share repurchase program," he warned.Deutsche Bank doesn't see leadership changing anytime soon — and if CEO Jeffrey Immelt does get the boot, Inch warned that "the next CEO could opt to significantly reset earnings targets lower: possibly closer to actual cash generation.""In turn, we expect the market could be negatively surprised by this prospective reset," he postulated.Immelt is under scrutiny by Trian Partners' Nelson Peltz. The activist investor has reportedly been displeased with the GE head's performance.Deutsche Bank said GE's $31 billion in underfunded pension obligations seems high and "could be considered a long term cash call on the company," adding that the company will contribute $1.8 billion to its pension plan in each of the next two years.GE's "inexplicably low" tax rate could actually be a risk, Inch said. If the White House and Congress can manage to revamp the tax code, GE is unlikely to benefit, given that its tax rate is already below what its peers are paying. And if the tax code were simplified and loopholes closed, that could lift GE's taxes.GE shares fell as low as 27.85, closing down 2.1% at 28.27 on the stock market today. GE stock has struggled for most of 2017 to retake support at its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Among other big industrial stocks, United Technologies (UTX) was off 0.4%, Honeywell (HON) lost 0.3%, and German rival Siemens (SIEGY) rose 3 cents to 71.21.RELATED:Will Microsoft Cloud GE's Industrial Internet Hopes? Not So FastGE Sees Digital Revenue More Than Doubling To $15 Billion By 2020How GE Could Become The Apple Of The Industrial InternetAmazon Cloud Services Under Growing Threat From Microsoft, Google, IBM

General Electric (GE) continues its transformation into what CEO Jeff Immelt calls a digital industrial company, with GE shares clearing a buy point in Thursday trading.GE has formed a first-stage cup-with-handle base over the last 50 days, with a 30.69 buy point.Shares rose 2.6% to 30.96 in above-average volume on the stock market today, almost back to break-even for 2016. The stock hit a 7-year high of 31.48 on Dec. 29.Other industrial conglomerates, like United Technologies (UTX), Honeywell (HON) and Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB), have made modest gains so far this year. A weaker dollar in the wake of the Federal Reserve's lowered rate hike path, along with a generally falling greenback in recent weeks, is lifting the prospects for big industrial multinationals.On Tuesday, GE said that it's adding 160 people focused solely on digital advancements in transportation and health care, including software engineers, developers and data scientists, to its Chicago operations.Meanwhile, GE continues to integrate Alstom's power and grid energy business after paying $10.6 billion for that part of the France-based company last November.With the Alstom purchase, GE has the world's largest installed base of electrical power generation equipment, with one-third of the world's electricity generated from GE technology, the company has said.GE's earnings per share growth shrank 7% in the fourth quarter of 2015. Its EPS growth is projected to be flat this quarter and dip a bit again in Q2 before surging in the back half of the year. GE is projected to report 90% year-over-year EPS growth in Q3.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Genpact (G) has made its mark helping companies operate more efficiently, but over the last two years the business processing firm has invested heavily to make its own firm run more effectively.The company, once an India-based arm of General Electric (GE), had gone through some growing pains. The outsourcer for hundreds of companies worldwide -- handling non-core functions such as accounting and finance -- decided it was time to be more selective in the businesses it pursued.Out of the loop went telecom, utilities and government, among other lackluster sectors. More attention was paid to financial services, manufacturing, consumer products, pharma and high tech -- and in finding new ways to service those customers."We’ve spent about $100 million-plus across a range of new capabilities to take the company to the next level, such as building out mobile and analytical solutions," Chief Executive N.V. "Tiger" Tyagarajan told IBD.Making such a move came with a price, though. Margins and earnings took a hit initially. In 2014, per-share earnings fell 9%. And as part of that, business from its largest client and former parent, GE, has shrunk to a fraction of what it was.But it’s a different picture now. The strategy to invest in client sectors with the best growth potential and dial back on smaller, less lucrative areas is starting to pay off."They basically decided to take down their profitability to strategically drive revenue in specific areas," analyst Joseph Foresi of Cantor Fitzgerald told IBD. "You’ve seen growth rates pick up and positive data points in bookings’ numbers."Genpact's total revenue in 2015 rose 8% over 2014 to $2.46 billion, but new bookings jumped 20%. Earnings for the year climbed 22% to $1.26 a share. In the fourth quarter, earnings grew 31% to 34 cents a share on revenue of $646.5 million, up 7% from the prior year.Revenue would have been higher had it not been negatively impacted by GE’s business divestitures. In the fourth quarter, GE revenue fell 1% year-over-year to $117 million, accounting for 18% of the total. Non-GE revenue from other global clients rose 10% to $529 million.For the full year, revenue from GE was down 1% to $460 million, representing 19% of total revenue. Global-client revenue grew 10% to $2 billion, or up 13% in constant currency.GE once accounted for 100% of Genpact’s revenue, when it was still an India-based business process management and information technology services arm of the massive U.S. conglomerate. In 2005, Genpact started providing services to non-GE clients, too, as an independent company. It went public in 2007.“As GE continues to change its portfolio, our relationship changes,” Tyagarajan said.About 60% of Genpact’s work is still performed in India. The rest is done in 18 other countries, including Romania, the Philippines, China, Mexico and Hungary. The company is headquartered in New York.The shrinking of GE’s contributions has been especially apparent since last March, when GE announced it would divest its financial services arm, GE Capital. Accelerated GE divestitures will weigh on 2016 results: Genpact expects GE revenue to fall 8% to 10% this year. But it forecasts that revenue from non-GE global clients will rise by 12.5% to 14%.Analysts expect total revenue this year to grow 7% to $2.64 billion, according to a poll by Thomson Reuters. Earnings are seen rising 12% to $1.42 a share.Tyagarajan doesn’t seem worried about lost business from GE.“As GE sells those businesses, it’s natural for us to enter into new relationships with the buyers. The work has to continue,” he said.Of the 12 GE Capital businesses sold so far, Genpact has already entered into contracts with four buyers, including Bank of Montreal (BMO). Tyagarajan says it’s in talks with the eight others.Meanwhile, the outsourcing of business and technology services is a market with a lot of growth left in it, he says.“So much change and disruption in technology is very good for us,” he said. “Our role is to help our clients think about change and help them change.”As Genpact has changed its focus, its client roster has fallen from more than 800 to roughly 700, though Tyagarajan says the value of its contracts has been growing.Clients range from drug-store retailer Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) to manufacturers such as Boeing (BA), Nissan Motor (NSANY) and Honeywell (HON). Consumer products customers include Mondelez (MDLZ) and Kimberly-Clark (KMB). In pharma, it counts AstraZeneca (AZN) and others among its clients.The company’s ties with GE are a "competitive advantage," noted analyst Frank Atkins of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey in a recent note to clients, which came with a buy rating and price target of 30.Among those advantages are GE’s culture of lean principles and systems. What’s more, he noted, many GE execs go on to management roles at other firms, creating an expanded network of potential new client wins for Genpact."Its relationship with GE and recent investments give it solid positioning versus competitors," Atkins wrote. The company also addresses more industry verticals than many of its peers, he said.Genpact competes with pure-play business process management providers WNS (WNS) and ExlService Holdings (EXLS), as well as business processing units of larger global consultancies such as Accenture (ACN) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH).Tata Consultancy Services, Wipro (WIT) and Infosys (INFY) are also rivals in certain areas."Genpact has a longer sales cycle than typical outsourcing companies," said Cantor Fitzgerald's Foresi, meaning it takes longer to land a sale and start servicing clients once a deal is signed. "So the business is potentially stickier."

Honeywell (HON) has scrapped its $90.7 billion bid for United Technologies (UTX), which said Friday that the offer undervalued United Tech, wouldn't pass muster with antitrust regulators and would ultimately harm the company.The decision to abandon the offer also follows trepidation over the deal expressed by Airbus (EADSY) and Boeing (BA), both of which are customers of the companies.Airbus' CEO said a merger between United Technologies and Honeywell was unlikely to "be in the interests of Airbus," while Boeing said "healthy competition in our supply chain is vitally important," according to the Wall Street Journal.Honeywell said it "strongly disagrees" with United Technologies' assessment of the offer and argued that the companies had been trying to get together for some time. The two companies, Honeywell CEO Dave Cote said, had been "talking about a combination for more than 15 years.""United Technologies felt the same way as we do when they approached us in May, 2011 and in April, 2015," Honeywell said in a statement.The company added: "In our approach to their chairman and their CEO on February 19, 2016, we had hoped to continue amicable and quiet discussions of a combination. In fact, we were told by them during the meeting that such a combination would be fabulous, they would take it very seriously, and they would get back to us with questions within a week in anticipation of their upcoming board meeting."However," Honeywell said, "continuing to try to negotiate with an unwilling partner is inconsistent with our disciplined acquisition process."Either way, Honeywell's acquisitive urges appeared to be intact.The company on Tuesday said it had bought RSI Video Technologies and Movilizer, which add video-verification security and cloud platforms that help manage workflow, to Honeywell's portfolio.The abandoned large bid for United Technologies and the two much smaller purchases come a day before Honeywell's investor day, when the company said it will present "a terrific growth story for standalone Honeywell."In a statement, United Tech said Honeywell's decision Tuesday is the "appropriate outcome given the strong regulatory obstacles, negative customer reaction and the potential for a protracted review process that would have destroyed shareholder value."United Tech shares closed down 1.6%. Honeywell climbed 4.5%. Boeing rose 1.5%, and Airbus added 3.1%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

United Technologies provided more reasons the industrial conglomerate isn't interested in merging with Honeywell (HON), which detailed its $90.7 billion offer Friday.United Tech CEO Gregory Hayes said the company concluded that antitrust regulators either would block the merger or would drag it out so long as to “destroy shareholder value far beyond any synergies.”A merger also would hurt the company's operations, customer relationships and talent retention, he added.And the proposal “grossly undervalues (United Technologies) and overstates potential synergies,” he said in a statement.“Effectively, Honeywell’s proposal is a leveraged buyout of UTC using UTC’s own strong balance sheet,” Hayes added.Earlier Friday, Honeywell disclosed the terms of its bid. Had the offer been accepted, United Technologies shareholders would have received $42.63 a share in cash and 0.614 share of Honeywell, according to the presentation.Honeywell valued the deal at around $108 a share, or $90.7 billion, in the cash-and-stock offer, using Feb. 18 prices.Honeywell has described the potential deal as a "significant synergy opportunity" with "significant value creation potential."On Monday, United Technologies said it never explored a Honeywell merger because of "regulatory obstacles, customer concerns and valuation issues."The proposed deal also has drawn the criticism of Airbus (EADSY), whose CEO, Tom Enders, described the merger as not being in the aircraft manufacturer's interests. Honeywell and United Technologies are two of Airbus's biggest suppliers.Honeywell shares closed 1.1% lower on the stock market today. United Technologies stock fell 0.4%. Airbus shares lost 1.5%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Honeywell (HON) reportedly is attempting to sell off its building-solutions unit, as Airbus has expressed opposition to the company's proposed merger with United Technologies (UTX).The possible sale could net Honeywell between $3 billion and $4 billion, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing sources. Bankers at Goldman Sachs (GS) are helping with the sales process, WSJ said. The building-solutions unit provides safety and other services to commercial buildings, according to WSJ.Meanwhile, Airbus (EADSY) CEO Tom Enders told the Financial Times that his company opposes a Honeywell-United Tech merger, saying a merger of two of its biggest suppliers "would not be in the interests" of the aircraft maker.France-based Airbus buys about $4.4 billion in components from United Tech each year, and its Pratt & Whitney engine-maker unit is Airbus' top supplier. Honeywell sells about $331 million worth of brakes, wheels and air conditioning systems each year to Airbus.Airbus and its rival, Boeing (BA), have pushed suppliers to bring down costs. A Honeywell-United Technologies merger presumably would do that, but would give the combined company unrivaled dominance in the market for certain aerospace components such as air conditioning systems, FT reported.Honeywell shares fell 0.3% to 103.30 on the stock market today. United Technologies stock climbed 2.2% to 93.61. Boeing shares fell 1.2% to 115.59.

Toyota Motor (TM) hired the entire 16-member engineering team at privately held Jaybridge Robotics, pushing toward its goal to among the leaders in the emerging autonomous self-driving car industry.Jaybridge and Toyota said that the former Jaybridge team, led by CEO Jeremy Brown, will join Toyota Research Institute (TRI) at its Cambridge, Mass. facility. No financial terms were given.Brown said in the statement that, “Where Jaybridge has historically limited its focus to industrial applications such as agriculture and mining, TRI is going after the big one: helping to reduce the nearly 1.25 million traffic fatalities each year, worldwide."Toyota is competing in an increasingly crowded field that includes Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google, General Motors (GM), Tesla Motors (TSLA) and other major automakers.It also includes Israel-based camera and software maker Mobileye (MBLY), whose systems are used by General Motors, Tesla in semi-autonomous driving features today. China Internet search giant Baidu (BIDU) -- which has a major Chinese ride-sharing venture with Uber -- has teamed with German automaker BMW to create self-driving cars.Toyota last year it would spend $1 billion on artificial intelligence, with an emphasis on autonomous driving.Jaybridge lists as some of its technology and business partners the U.S. Army and Navy, diversified auto and aerospace manufacturer Honeywell (HON), autonomous underwater vehicles maker Bluefin Robotics and Harvest Automation, which makes robotic equipment for industrial and agricultural uses.Toyota's stock has fallen 27% in just under a year amid weakening sales, sliding from an all-time intraday high at 145.80 on March 23, 2015 to a 106.25 close. Toyota fell 0.4% on the stock market today.Alphabet climbed 1.7% at 725.41 and General Motors was down 0.5% at 30.54, while Tesla Motors climbed 3% to 208.70. Mobileye edged up a few cents to 33.62 and Baidu rose 2.2% to 176.53.

U.S. stocks extended their gains in early afternoon trading Thursday, despite a dip oil prices and a big sell-off in Chinese stocks.The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.5% advance, while the S&P 500 held a 0.4% gain. The Nasdaq rose a fraction. Volume was tracking lower across the board vs. the same time Wednesday, indicating many institutional investors were sitting on the sidelines. Winners outpaced losers by about 5-to-4 on the NYSE, but decliners topped advancers by the same margin on the Nasdaq.United Technologies (UTX) led the Dow, advancing more than 4% in fast trade. Shares have risen 11% since Monday, when reports of a potential merger with Honeywell (HON) surfaced. United Technologies soared past its 50-day moving average that day and is now 2% below its converged 200-day line. Honeywell was slightly higher.Home furnishings retailers led the downside among IBD's 197 industry groups, dropping 5% as Restoration Hardware (RH) gapped down and crashed 28% after the luxury furnishings chain late Wednesday offered disappointing preliminary Q4 guidance. Shares are 64% below their 52-week high.Oil stocks also lagged, as West Texas Intermediate crude slipped 1.8% to $31.57 a barrel. It remains up nearly 7% for the week, however. Among other gainers were meat products, foreign banks and financial services stocks.Though the restaurant group was slightly lower, Domino's Pizza (DPZ) surged 12% to a new high, clearing a 119.83 buy point in hefty trade. The pizza delivery and takeout chain reported Q4 earnings and sales well above forecasts, as well as a 10.7% increase in U.S. same-store sales.On the IBD 50, NetEase (NTES) gapped down by 15%, breaching its 200-day line in rapid turnover. The Chinese online company late Wednesday reported Q4 results that topped views, but gross margin was lower than Q3 and the prior year. Credit Agricole downgraded the Chinese online company to underperform from outperform. However, JPMorgan held its rating at overweight and raised the stock's price target to 185, from 181.

X Lockheed Martin (LMT) and Raytheon (RTN) were among firms that promised tech transfers and local development as part of $150 billion in deals with Saudi Arabia announced during President Trump's visit over the weekend.Technology transfers and local production could boost the kingdom's industrial know-how as it diversifies away from oil and potentially reduces its dependence on U.S.-made products, despite Trump's "America first" policy promise. However, some of the deals were negotiated under the Obama administration, and many aren't finalized yet, with more negotiations needed.Lockheed said in a release that Saudi Arabia wants to buy more than $28 billion in "integrated air and missile defense, combat ship, tactical aircraft and rotary wing technologies and programs."A letter of intent was singed with Saudi tech firm Taqnia to form a joint venture to support the completion of 150 S-70 Black Hawk helicopters.Lockheed has been eager to offer technology transfers and joint-venture opportunities to boost its market share overseas. The company wants 30% of all sales to be from foreign allies in the coming years.Last year, Lockheed offered tech transfers and offered to move its F-16 manufacturing line to India to secure a massive fighter jet order from New Delhi.Lockheed shares closed up 1.55% at 277.03 on the stock market today, still in buy range.The maker of Tomahawk cruise missiles and the Patriot air-defense system announced plans to form Raytheon Arabia, a Raytheon branch that will focus on boosting local Saudi defense and security capabilities.Shares finished 0.6% higher at 161.19, also still in buy range.The aerospace giant didn't give total figures for its agreements, which include a deal for Chinook helicopter and support services, guided-weapons systems and the P-8 reconnaissance plane.Boeing (BA) also announced a joint venture to provide sustainment services on military platforms as part of the Saudi Vision 2030 economic reform program Saudi Arabia announced last year to help ease its dependence on oil revenue.On the commercial side, Saudi Gulf Airlines said it would negotiate buying up to 16 widebody airplanes.Boeing shares rallied 1.6% to 183.67, trying to regain their 185.81 buy point.General Electric (GE) announced $15 billion in deals. GE said it will also provide digital technology for Saudi Aramco, the state-run oil company. Aramco announced $50 billion in agreements with U.S. companies, with $200 billion in overall deals.But GE noted that some of the deals were just memorandums of understanding, which need more deal-making before they are finalized.GE shares edged up 0.5% to 28.18.National Oilwell Varco (NOV) announced a joint venture to make specialty drilling rigs and equipment in Saudi Arabia. The deal will include $6 billion in investment over the next decade.Dow Chemical (DOW) said it would build a polymer and coatings plant in Saudi Arabia.Honeywell (HON) signed a $3.6 billion memorandum of understanding to localize products in Aramco's supply chain.RELATED: Defense And Aerospace Stocks To Watch And Industry NewsEnergy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, Coal

China successfully completed the first test flight of its home-built modern passenger jet, bolstering President  Xi Jinping's ambition of turning China into an advanced economy.Amid cheers from onlookers, the C919 airliner took off Friday from Pudong International Airport in Shanghai, the home base of its builder Commercial Aircraft Corp. of China Ltd., or Comac. The jet landed back about an hour and 19 minutes later after cruising at 3,000 meters (9,840 feet). The single-aisle plane, which is designed to seat as many as 174 people, is slated to enter commercial service with China Eastern Airlines Corp. in 2019."It shows China made a historic breakthrough in its years-old dream of building a big aircraft," Comac said in a statement, calling the test a "complete success." The nation's State Council, the top administrative authority, sent a congratulatory note to the designers.The test flight, after repeated delays, marks another step in Xi's ambitious 'Made in China 2025' program, which identified aerospace among sectors that could accelerate China's advancement. The government has said the ability to build and fly a large commercial aircraft is the "flower'' and "pearl'' of modern manufacturing.The C919 would be the first major competitor for Airbus SE and Boeing Co. in the most popular sector of the airliner market and gives Comac a home advantage in what is set to become the world's biggest aircraft market. Boeing estimates China will need 6,810 aircraft worth more than $1 trillion in the two decades through 2035."There's a lot riding on the C919,'' said Xu Yongling, a military test pilot and a member of the Beijing-based Chinese Society of Aeronautics and Astronautics. "The expectation for the C919 is not to become the best-selling single-aisle aircraft in the market, but rather become a stepping stone for COMAC to build something better, with indigenous technology.''COMAC plans to make six planes for tests, and the second one is getting ready at the final assembly workshop in Shanghai, the builder said. Guests who witnessed Friday's test flight included Vice Premier Ma Kai and Han Zheng, Communist Party secretary from Shanghai.The five people on board the test plane were the captain, co-pilot, an observer and two engineers.Getting into the major league with Airbus (EADSY) and Boeing (BA) may be a few decades away as customers typically prefer aircraft with proven track record, reliability and safety, analysts said. COMAC is seeking certification for the C919 from European agencies."Comac could well be an option for us," said William Walsh, chief executive officer of IAG SA, the owner of British Airways Plc, adding he'd only seriously consider the plane when IAG reviews its existing fleet of short-haul Airbus A320-family jets in the long-term. More immediately, he's expecting lower prices from the added competition.Walsh, a former pilot who's flown in the plane's simulator, said he's due to meet with Comac next month to further advise on features that IAG looks for in a new model."A new entrant will have an impact on pricing," Walsh told analysts on a call Friday. "We've seen that to some degree with the launch of the CSeries. It's something that both airlines and the manufacturers are aware of."The C919 designation was chosen partly to reflect the idea of long life in Chinese numerology.With a maximum range of 3,450 miles, the plane is powered by two LEAP-1C engines from CFM International Inc., a joint venture between Safran SA and General Electric (GE). Other key system suppliers include Honeywell International (HON), Rockwell Collins (COL), Liebherr-International Deutschland GmbH, Thales SA and Panasonic Corp.The test flight of the plane follows China's launch last month of its first domestically built aircraft carrier. The milestones, coming within weeks, burnish Xi's credentials as a modernizer before he presides over the ruling Communist Party's twice-a-decade congress later this year.Almost a billion people will fly to, from or within China by 2025, the International Air Transport Association estimates. Over the next two decades, about 75 percent of the jets ferrying those passengers will be single-aisle -- a category dominated by Boeing's 737 and Airbus's A320 family.In an email, Boeing congratulated Comac for the "successful development" of the C919, while Airbus said it welcomes competition, "which is good for the development of the industry."Comac, which had postponed the test flight at least twice, says it has commitments from 23 customers for about 570 planes, with Shanghai-based China Eastern lined up to take the first delivery.Richard Aboulafia, an aerospace analyst at Teal Group, said China may have to wait till its next aircraft to really break the duopoly for jets that can carry more than 100 passengers."At the moment, they are in a real replication mode, which is not where you want to be," he said. "First off, they need to privatize and open their supply chain up to a global network, rather than just people who will transfer yesterday's technology."Comac has set its sights on building a wide-body aircraft. It is forming a joint venture with Russia's United Aircraft Corp. to develop a twin-aisle jet."The C919 is a testament to China's civil aviation research and manufacturing capability," said Yu Zhanfu, executive director at Roland Berger Management Consultants Shanghai Co. "China's had a lot of success in making rockets, making spaceships. It shows the country is capable of mega tech-intensive manufacturing projects."

Western Digital (WDC) filed for arbitration Sunday to prevent partner Toshiba from selling its stake in their memory chip joint venture, a move that would delay any transaction. Hard drive maker Western Digital, has a joint venture with the Japanese tech giant via its acquisition of flash memory maker SanDisk, says it must have a say."Toshiba's attempt to spin out its joint venture interests into an affiliate and then sell that affiliate is explicitly prohibited without SanDisk's consent," said Western Digital CEO Steve Milligan in a statement.Toshiba is trying to shed assets to raise enough cash to stay afloat, with U.S. nuclear unit Westinghouse filing for bankruptcy in March. Possible bidders for Toshiba's chip business include Broadcom (AVGO), SK Hynix and Apple (AAPL) iPhone maker Hon Hai Precision Industry — or Foxconn.Broadcom cleared a 227.85 buy point last week, rising to 235.90 on Friday, still in range. Broadcom, which is also an Apple supplier.Western Digital has mulled making its own bid for Toshiba's JV stake, perhaps in conjunction with a quasi-state Japanese entities. Western Digital rose out of buy range following its solid earnings and strong guidance last month.

General Electric (GE) reported second-quarter earnings of 51 cents a share excluding various items, up 64.5% vs. a year earlier despite a weak global economy.  Sales jumped 15% to $33.49 billion. But orders and organic revenue fell.It was the best EPS gain since Q1 2011 for the industrial giant and the best sales increase in years.Analysts had expected General Electric to report 46 cents a share, up 48%. Revenue was seen climbing 8.3% to $31.77 billion.GE Power revenue shot up 31% and renewable energy 28%, fueled by the $10 billion takeover of Alstom's energy business. But oil and gas unit revenue tumbled 22%. Digital segment revenue climbed 17%.Meanwhile, industrial organic revenue fell 1% to $24.4 billion, below some estimates. Orders fell 2% to $12.9 billion.General Electric reaffirmed 2016 operating EPS guidance for $1.45-$1.55.General Electric fell 2.4% to 31.81 on the stock market today, undercutting a 32.15 buy point cleared on July 8. The stock hit an 8-year high of 33 Wednesday.Separately, Honeywell (HON) reported adjusted EPS of $1.66, up 10% vs. a year earlier and 2 cents above views. But the diversified industrial firm's revenue of $10 billion missed views for $10.1 billion. Honeywell stock sank nearly 5% to 113 soon after the open, tumbling below its 50-day line. Shares fell 1% to 118.66 on Thursday after hitting a record 120 intraday.IBD'S TAKE: Buying a stock before earnings can pay off handsomely, or blow up in your face. The pros of cons of buying or holding a stock ahead of its earnings report are explored in this Investor's Corner.

Your Investing Action Plan for Friday: What you need to know as an investor for the coming day. Diversified industrial giants General Electric (GE) and Honeywell (HON) will report second-quarter results Friday morning on a light day for earnings. Those companies' results and outlooks will offer clues about big industrials and the global economy. Investors also will get an early read…

General Electric (GE) reported its best profit gain in more than five years on Friday. But GE shares fell, as key metrics weakened.Earnings per share minus one-time items soared 65% to 51 cents a share, beating estimates by 5 cents. Revenue rose 15% to $33.49 billion, also better than expected, helped by recent acquisitions. GE's Power, Aviation and Healthcare divisions were strong, offsetting drops in Oil & Gas and TransportationBut industrial orders tumbled 16% excluding recent acquisitions. Organic industrial revenue dipped 1%, below some forecasts, though GE stuck to its 2%-4% growth forecast for the full year. GE shares closed 1.6% lower at 32.06 in the stock market today, just below a 32.15 buy point cleared earlier this month. Shares hit an eight-year high of 33 on Wednesday.General Electric has sold off an array of GE Capital assets over the past year, enabling it to have its designation as a systemically important financial institution removed during Q2. That means it faces fewer regulatory restrictions going forward."We will continue to invest in key growth initiatives such as GE Digital, while returning about $26 billion to investors through buyback and dividends," GE CEO Jeff Immelt said in the company's second-quarter earnings statement Friday.GE reaffirmed its full-year 2016 operating EPS outlook for $1.45-$1.55, the midpoint just below analyst views for $1.51.IBD'S TAKE: General Electric and Honeywell had hit long-time highs recent, but the industrial giants aren't leaders. To see how GE and Honeywell stack up vs. objective criteria, go to IBD Stock Checkup.Revenue for the company's Power business jumped 31% to $6.64 billion, boosted by the $10 billion acquisition of Alstom's energy business. GE ended the quarter with 34 of its HA gas turbine systems in backlog. During Q2, GE announced an agreement to buy the Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG) business from South Korea's Doosan Engineering & Construction for $250 million.GE announced more $25 billion in aerospace orders and commitments at the Farnborough Air Show earlier this month for GE and its partner companies, and GE's Aviation revenue rose 4% in Q2 to $6.5 billion.The manufacturer's health systems revenue was also up 4% to $4.53 billion as GE opened a biopharmaceutical facility for JHL Biotech in China, and China orders rose 9% for the quarter.Although GE signed an order for $51 million worth of railroad locomotives for Brazil in Q2, total Transportation division revenue fell 13% to $1.24 billion.Revenue for GE's appliances and lighting business plunged 25% to $1.67 billion, although the company was able to offset some of the drop with $70 million in internal cost savings "by implementing solar solutions for 18 GE sites."Petroleum prices began edging up in Q2 from multiyear lows but were still at a low level. GE's Oil & Gas revenue slid 22% to $3.22 billion from $4.12 billion a year earlier. Looking ahead, its oil and gas services backlog rose 15% during the quarter.The company didn't initially break out digital revenue. But GE Chief Digital Officer Bill Ruh said last month he sees the company's digital business generating about $7 billion revenue this year and $15 billion by 2020. During the quarter, GE announced a partnership with Microsoft (MSFT) to bring its GE's Predix operating system for the Industrial Internet to Microsoft's Azure cloud.Honeywell (HON) also reported Q2 results Friday. Adjusted EPS rose 10% vs. a year earlier to $1.66, topping estimates by 2 cents a share. Revenue edged up 2.1% to $9.99 billion, lighter than the expected $10.13 billion.Honeywell on Friday announced it's splitting its Automation & Control Solutions (ACS) business into two new segments: Home and Building Technologies (HBT) and Safety and Productivity Solutions (SPS).The diversified automobile and aerospace manufacturer narrowed its full-year EPS guidance to $6.60-$6.70, the midpoint just below analyst consensus for $6.66. Honeywell now sees organic revenue falling this year vs. its prior target for a 1%-2% gain.Honeywell fell 3.5% to 114.49 in afternoon trade, below its 50-day line but off its morning low of 112.70. On Thursday, Honeywell hit a record intraday high of 120.

United Technologies (UTX) stock has finally formed its first pattern of 2016, and it's been working through a flat base for going on two months.The question is: Can United Technologies move into a buy range where other large diversified manufacturers such as 3M (MMM), Honeywell (HON) and General Electric (GE) are currently positioned?United Technologies makes aircraft engines via its Pratt & Whitney unit, as well as Otis brand elevators, heating and security systems and other aerospace components and systems. Its stock took a drubbing early in the year but it's risen 25% since hitting a 2016 low at 83.39 on Jan. 20.It's following similar patterns by 3M, maker of various medical supplies and office supplies, and Honeywell, which makes automotive and aerospace systems. They both sank early this year in sync with the sharp early-2016 market pullback and then recovered. Shares of both recently climbed into record territory.General Electric, largest of the quartet with roughly $119 billion annual sales, hasn't slipped this year but continued its slow, steady climb as it transforms into what it calls a digital industrial company, rolling out its Predix Industrial internet operating system and industrial manufacturing software. Its stock, though, is still well below its all-time high.Mining equipment giant Caterpillar (CAT), with $43.8 billion annual sales, has moved into buy territory as well. Like United Technologies, Caterpillar is forming a first-stage flat base, and it has an 80.99 buy point. Its stock has risen on hopes that the long commodities price slump is nearing an end amid higher prices for crude oil and some metals.While 3M, Honeywell and GE are in buy range, United Technologies is working its way through that flat base. Shares were on track for a fifth straight higher close on Tuesday amid new contacts and announcements at the Farnborough Air Show in England. Just before the show, on July 8, Pratt & Whitney received a contract valued at $1.5 billion from the Department of Defense to manufacture F135 engines for all three variations of the F-35 Lightning II Joint Strike Fighter jet.IBD'S TAKE: United Technologies and a number of other big-name industrial stocks are in buy range, but many don't have high composite ratings from IBD. For a listing on the highest-rated stocks, try IBD's MarketSmith.However, on Monday Qatar Airways at the show said it was looking at buying 30 Boeing (BA) 737s in place of Europe's Airbus Group's (EADSY) A320neos. The carrier canceled delivery of one A320neo saying it found glitches in the Pratt & Whitney engines. Qatar Airways has been in talks with the CFM joint venture between GE and France's Safran S.A. to provide an alternative engine but no deal had been reached as of early Tuesday.United Technologies shares were up 0.5% at 104.50 in Tuesday afternoon trading on the stock market today. It was trading in the upper half of the first stage flat base, with a 107.17 buy point.GE rose 0.2%, Honeywell 0.4% and 3M 0.7% Tuesday.

The stock market took a breather Thursday as earnings results continued to drive big moves in both directions ahead of reports from Chipotle (CMG), Starbucks (SBUX) and Visa (V). EBay (EBAY) soared, while Intel (INTC) sank during the regular trading session.The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.4% each; the Nasdaq gave up 0.3%. Volume was higher on the NYSE and Nasdaq vs. Wednesday, according to early figures.After the close, Starbucks fell 4% on a revenue miss. Chipotle missed earnings views, but shares were slightly higher in extended trading.Software, automakers and airlines led the downside during the regular session in the stock market today, while gold miners, medical and leisure stocks represented the upside.Construction machinery stocks also outperformed, as Joy Global (JOY) surged 20% in massive volume on a $3.7 billion acquisition by Japan's Komatsu (KMTUY).EBay gapped up and soared 11% to a new high, clearing a 29.93 buy point in fast turnover. The stock has now advanced in 11 of the past 12 sessions. After the close Wednesday, the online marketplace reported Q2 results that topped views and guided its full-year outlook above forecasts.Qualcomm (QCOM) vaulted 7% to its best level since November on a quarterly earnings and sales beat. Shares of the chip designer are 8% off a 52-week high but still nearly 50% below its July 2014 peak.Among IBD 50 stocks, LGI Homes (LGIH) was the clear winner, with a 4% jump in heavy trade.On the downside, Intel gapped down and fell 4% in heavy volume after reporting mixed Q2 results late Wednesday. Shares fell back into buy range from a 32.85 flat-base entry first cleared June 30.In economic news, initial jobless claims dipped to 253,000 the week ended July 16, down from 254,000 the prior week and below economists' projections for an increase to 260,000 claims.Existing-home sales climbed 1.1% in June to an annualized rate of 5.57 million, the best in more than nine years. Tight supply drove prices up 4.8% from last year.A light economic report schedule Friday includes the flash manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index for July.Earnings results are also due out from American Airlines (AAL), General Electric (GE) and Honeywell (HON).

Airbus (EADSY) edged out Boeing (BA) Thursday in the commercial orders race at the Paris Air Show, which saw stronger-than-expected demand for new passenger jets.The European aerospace giant received orders for a total of 421 aircraft, worth $57 billion at list prices. Boeing received orders and commitments for 331 planes valued at $50.2 billion. Buyers typically get undisclosed discounts for large orders.The combined tally of 752 eclipsed forecasts for a weak year as record backlogs and saturated growth markets were expected to weigh on demand. Before the show, Cowen analyst Cai von Rumohr predicted that Boeing and Airbus would have less than the average of 387 orders combined.Boeing shares closed up 1.4% on the stock market today. Airbus dipped 0.7%. Aerospace supplier United Technologies (UTX), which owns engine maker Pratt & Whitney, rose 0.7%. Honeywell (HON) gained 1.3%, and General Electric (GE) edged up 0.4%.This year's tally also topped last year's total of 687 at the Farnborough Airshow, which alternates with the Paris show each year. But Airbus' total was down from last year, when it received orders and commitments for 486 aircraft. Boeing's orders were up this year, as it had deals for just 201 planes at Farnborough.The 2015 number was also down from the 2013 Paris Air Show, which saw orders for 908 aircraft between the two aerospace giants. Blockbuster deals two years ago were led by new planes, including Airbus' A320neo and Boeing's 737 Max and 787 Dreamliner. Those planes have more fuel-efficient engines that were in demand at a time of high oil prices.But while the orders from the past week came in higher than expected, the Paris Air Show failed to impress some analysts."There weren't any huge surprises there," said Robert Mann, president of aviation consultancy R.W. Mann & Co. "I don't think anyone took home a trophy — unless in the Little League sense where everyone gets a trophy."The Paris show's orders point to capacity increases in Asia, with China and Indonesia leading the way, he added. Garuda Indonesia, the country's flagship carrier, was among the big buyers at Paris, making deals to buy 30 Dreamliners and 30 737 Max jets from Boeing and 30 A350s from Airbus.Capacity should grow slightly in Eastern Europe, but Mann said most of the orders from the region will be for replacement planes.Major deals in prior shows came from Middle Eastern carriers, which kept a low profile this year as tensions with European and U.S. carriers heat up over capacity increases and competitive practices.Qatar Airway's A380 was featured at the show, but the airline didn't announce any big deals, like the 50-plane order it announced with Boeing at the 2014 Farnborough Airshow.No new planes from the two aircraft giants debuted at the show this year, though there was plenty of buzz over Boeing's acknowledgment that it's looking at a new mid-size plane and is already talking to potential customers about its requirements.Boeing was on track to finish the Paris show with the most orders, helped by a deal from aircraft lessor AerCap (AER) for 100 737 Max jets.But Wizz Air, a low-cost European carrier, made a provisional agreement at the last minute for 110 A321neos, worth $12.5 billion, putting Airbus in the lead. Airbus had forecast only 200 total orders and commitments at Paris.Both Boeing and Airbus must now manage bulging backlogs and plans to ramp up production rates. The companies have a combined backlog of 12,000 planes. Airbus is boosting output of its popular A320 airliner by nearly 20% to 50 per month in 2017. Boeing is lifting production of its 737 to 52 planes per month in 2018 vs. 42 currently.Supply chain issues may curb production growth. Last year, Air Lease (AL) COO John Plueger called the increase in Boeing and Airbus production a "major concern" and that suppliers are operating at "absolute capacity." GE has opened seven new engine parts plants in seven years to help keep up.Orders are expected to keep rolling in over the long term. Boeing sees demand for over 38,000 airplanes in the next two decades, with single-aisle planes the most sought after. Airbus sees demand for 32,600 new planes in the next 20 years.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter: @IBD_GRich.

Orders for durable goods rose the most in 10 months in January, boosted by gains in aircraft and core capital goods orders, the Commerce Department said Thursday.Big-ticket, long-lasting orders shot up 4.9%, the most since last March and following two months of declines. Economists forecast a 2% gain. January's total was near the upper end of the consensus range too.December's number was revised upward 0.5 point to a 4.6% decline. Year over year, durable goods orders rose 0.6%.Excluding transportation equipment, orders still rose 1.8% compared to December. But they fell 2.5% vs. a year earlier.Civilian aircraft orders shot up 54% after tumbling 29% in December, reflecting the monthly swings in demand for Boeing (BA) jets and other planes.Core capital goods orders, which exclude aircraft and defense, climbed 3.9% for the month. The business investment proxy had fallen in the prior two months. Core capital goods still slid 4.4% vs. a year earlier, the 13th straight decline. The energy and mining sectors have slashed investment as prices and demand for oil and other commodities tumble.It remains to be seen whether January's positive durable goods orders bodes well for U.S. factories or whether it's merely a blip on the radar screen. Durable goods orders are notoriously volatile.For February, the PMI manufacturing flash index and the Richmond Federal Reserve both reported disappointing manufacturing data. The Kansas City Fed's regional manufacturing index tumbled to -12, the worst since April 2009 low.Factories have been hit hard by a strong dollar and slowing economic growth overseas. The struggling energy sector also has impacted manufacturing.Top manufacturers were up on the stock market today. Boeing rose 1.1%. Whirlpool (WHR) added 0.2%. Honeywell (HON) gained 0.6%, United Techologies (UTX) surged 4.8% and General Electric (GE) rallied 0.4%.Honeywell and United Technologies have held merger talks, but United Tech is worried about antitrust concerns for the aerospace components makers.

Aerospace company Honeywell (HON) soared past a buy point Monday after news that the company was in merger talks, but then the stock reversed sharply lower. Honeywell shares surged as much as 4%, topping the 107.51 buy point of a pattern that stretched out to August. But the stock closed with a loss of 2.10 to 105.17. Volume was nearly…

Honeywell (HON) and United Technologies (UTX) reportedly have discussed merging, as the two industrial companies endure headwinds from a strong dollar and weak global economic growth.The negotiations occurred within the last two weeks and focused on the Morris Plains, N.J.-based Honeywell, which initiated the latest talks, offering a premium in stock and some cash for the Farmington, Conn.-based United Technologies, CNBC reported, citing sources. But United Technologies  is concerned about antitrust objections, with the Wall Street Journal later reporting that United Tech had rebuffed Honeywell on those grounds.Such a deal would create a combined company with $94 billion in sales.A  merger of the two companies that provide so much airplane material likely would face opposition from Boeing (BA) and Airbus (EADSY). United Technologies' Pratt & Whitney unit manufactures aircraft engines for Boeing and others.Honeywell shares fell 2% to 105.17l on the stock market today after initially spiking to a record high of 111.86. United Technologies stock climbed 4.7% to 92.37 after hitting 94.91 intraday. United Tech shares closed above their 50-day moving average for the first time this year.

Activist investors Altimeter Capital Management and PAR Capital Management on Tuesday said they would nominate six candidates to United Airlines’ (UAL) board of directors later this year, blasting the airline's directorship appointments a day earlier as a rushed, "cynical attempt to preserve power by this entrenched board."The wrangling over United's board is the latest jolt in what has been a bumpy ride at the company's corporate level, and comes amid the company's attempts to better compete with rivals Delta Air Lines (DAL) and American Airlines (AAL).United called the funds' move a "hostile action" that could take focus away from CEO Oscar Munoz's plan to turn the company around as he prepares to return to work full-time on March 14. Munoz suffered a heart attack in October, forcing him to take medical leave.United shares closed down 2.2% in the stock market today. Delta dropped 4.5%, and American slipped 3.2%.The two hedge funds -- longtime United investors that, combined, own around 7.1% of the company's stock -- said in a letter Tuesday that "meaningful change to United's existing board of directors is urgently required in order to reverse long-standing poor board governance and the resulting many years of substantial and inexcusable company underperformance relative to United's competitors."They also said that despite weeks of talks over changes to the board, United "hurriedly added" three new directors and expanded the board to 15 from 12.United argued that it "repeatedly" expressed an openness to changing the company's board, offered to extend its March 12 director nomination deadline, and said the funds "refused to cooperate in making their nominees available to be interviewed."The company also defended the three independent directors named yesterday as having "deep relevant experience" and backed the airline, citing last year's sky-high profits and improved on-time performance.Altimeter and PAR said they would nominate their candidates at United's annual stockholder meeting this year. They are Gordon Bethune, a former CEO of Continental Airlines and a board member of aerospace tech firm Honeywell (HON); Altimeter founder Brad Gerstner; Tina Sharkey, the CEO of SherpaFoundry; Barney Harford, former CEO of travel site Orbitz; Rodney O'Neal, ex-CEO of Delphi Automotive; and Brenda Yester Baty, the strategic initiatives chief at Lennar (LEN).Even as the fight among the suits escalated, United continued, as other airlines have, to quietly reinvest in making flying more pleasant.The company on Tuesday said it would retire its 747 fleet from scheduled service by the end of 2018. It also ordered 25 Boeing (BA) 737-700 planes, adding to an earlier order of 40 such aircraft. United is set to have the planes delivered at the end of next year.United seeks to shrink its regional fleet of 50-seat aircraft, and the 737s are bigger and more fuel-efficient planes.Those will have bigger overhead bins, along with an interior that "creates a larger sense of space through sculpted sidewall panels and LED cabin lighting that mimics soft blue skies and sunset colors."The orders continue a shift among the bigger carriers away from smaller jets. That trend, the Wall Street Journal noted, contributed to regional carrier Republic Airways’ (RJET) filing for bankruptcy protection last month.Image provided by Shutterstock.

The main stock indexes were lower, off by more than 1% in late trading.The Nasdaq tumbled 1.2%, the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were down 1.1%. Small caps were doing better, with the Russell 2000 off by 0.4%.Volume was slightly lower on the Nasdaq and running higher on the NYSE.The market has been following oil prices, and crude closed 4.5% lower. Saudi Arabia's oil minister doused hopes for a cut in output. Energy stocks were among the weakest of the day in the stock market.But leading stocks fared relatively better, with the IBD 50 basically flat in late trade. The retail sector was higher, even though today's report on consumer confidence was disappointing.Restaurants were up. Texas Roadhouse (TXRH) surged 11% as it broke out of a saucer-type base with a 40.92 buy point. The restaurant late Monday beat profit and sales expectations for Q4.Tobacco giant Altria Group (MO) topped the 61.84 buy point of a flat base. Shares also have climbed above the 61.48 alternate entry.Honeywell (HON) slid 1% in heavy trading and is now below a 107.51 buy point. Shares of the aerospace company surged Monday on word of a possible merger with United Technologies (UTX), but the stock reversed sharply lower, and the selling spilled over into today's session.Earnings reports slammed some noteworthy stocks. Store Capital (STOR) skidded 3% in active turnover despite the real estate investment trust's Q4 results that topped expectations. The company backed its 2016 guidance of adjusted funds from operations per share of $1.59 to $1.63.

With hotels in 87 countries, Marriott International (MAR) is finding it harder to protect itself from currency swings, as exchange rates in the $5.3-trillion-a-day market defy expectations.The chain locked in its 2016 currency hedges about four months ago, anticipating the dollar would extend a three-year winning streak. Instead, the greenback has had a mixed performance, slumping against the euro and yen this year amid turmoil in global markets. That’s a problem because the cost of the hedges would be wasted if the dollar weakens.“For better or for worse, you are locking in,” said Leeny Oberg, Marriott’s chief financial officer, in a telephone interview from Bethesda, Md. The company set hedges in 2016 with anticipation that the U.S. currency will strengthen, but less than last year.The dollar’s gain in 2015 and surging volatility squeezed revenue for Marriott, McDonald’s (MCD) and other companies that sell goods or services overseas, triggering some headaches for finance executives. It made sense for corporate treasurers to hedge against the dollar’s rally in 2015, which was widely predicted by analysts.This year, the task is becoming trickier as currency forecasts, which corporate treasurers use as a guide of where to hedge, have been upended. Options prices imply that, since the start of December, when some treasurers would have been firming up 2016 hedges, the chances of the greenback strengthening beyond the median year-end forecast of $1.08 per euro have fallen to 37% from 48%. The likelihood of it reaching the median estimate of 121 yen has plunged to 19% from 49%.The dollar’s path hinges on whether the Federal Reserve can keep raising interest rates while its biggest peers expand stimulus and the specter of a global slowdown threatens to derail the tightening cycle.Hundreds of companies in North America and Europe blamed currencies for hurting earnings last year, according to Scottsdale, Ariz.-based FiREapps, which makes software to help businesses reduce the effect of currency swings. Foreign exchange shaved 9% from McDonald’s full-year earnings per share and chopped more than $17 billion from Wal-Mart Stores’ (WMT) sales last year.A surging dollar decreases the value of overseas sales when they’re translated into the U.S. currency for the purpose of reporting earnings. If the revenue is left in the foreign country and not actually exchanged into dollars, the decline is on paper only. The strong dollar also hurts U.S. companies by making imported goods cheaper while U.S. exports are more expensive in foreign markets."Companies are getting hit big-time by foreign exchange," said Niklas Bergentoft, a New York-based director at Deloitte & Touche LLP, who co-authored a report on corporate hedging published this week. "We see this continuing for 2016." Deloitte surveyed 133 corporations with revenue ranging from $1 billion to more than $50 billion.For companies in the S&P 500 index, a 1% gain in the trade-weighted dollar lowers collective revenue by about 0.3 percentage point, said Stewart Warther, an equity strategist with BNP Paribas in New York. A Fed gauge of the trade-weighted dollar rallied 11% last year and 8% in 2014. The biggest risk is it keeps going for another year.“All our hedges expired for 2015, and you move into 2016, and there’s a reset for everyone back to the market,” said Tom Szlosek, chief financial officer of Honeywell International (HON).The maker of industrial goods ranging from aircraft engines to gas detectors locked in hedges for the euro at $1.10 this year, said Szlosek, whose treasury team reports to him monthly on currency movements. The euro rose 0.5% for the week to $1.0984 as of 6:41 a.m. New York time Friday.Last year, the company offset about 85% of its euro exposure at $1.24, limiting the hit from foreign exchange to 10 cents of full-year earnings per share, which was $6.04. This year, the lower hedge level means foreign-exchange effects may reduce annual earnings by as much as 15 cents a share, he said.For Marriott, dollar strength will probably reduce the fees it collects for managing hotels by $30 million this year because about a quarter of this year’s estimated $2.02 billion in fee revenue will come from outside the U.S., Oberg said.The company uses forward contracts to manage its exposure to the yen, euro, pound and Canadian dollar, because they’re the most actively traded currencies and cheapest to hedge. These contracts cover about one-third of foreign revenue from hotel management fees.Hedges in 2015 helped keep the decline from foreign exchange at $32 million of fee revenue, said Oberg, who declined to say at what level Marriott has hedged for 2016.“The currencies did move farther than I think people expected,” she said. “So, it was very helpful to have the hedges.”About 90% of companies use derivatives, including forwards and swaps, to offset their currency exposure, the Deloitte study showed. Most surveyed firms hedged an average of 68% of their cash flow for three months -- that hedge ratio dropped down to 59% of transactions for three to six months in the future, then fell to 50% for six months to a year ahead.McDonald’s said it expects the dollar to strengthen this year, but at a slower pace, knocking off about 20 cents from earnings per share in 2016 following a 50-cent hit last year. The company focuses its hedging on the euro, pound, Canadian and Australian dollars and yen, said Becca Hary, a spokeswoman. The hamburger chain only hedges for operations reasons and not for the accounting effect when translating foreign currencies to the dollar for earnings reports, she said.Wal-Mart’s decline in sales because of weaker foreign currencies last year was “by far” the largest ever for the retailer, David Cheesewright, chief of the company’s international operations, said on a Feb. 18 conference call. Wal-Mart expects the strong dollar to drive down sales by $12 billion this year.Companies that have manufacturing plants in foreign countries, such as Honeywell, can mitigate the fallout from currency fluctuations with “natural hedges” by keeping costs in the local money, Szlosek said. Honeywell, which has factories in countries such as Mexico and Hungary, says that including exports it generates about 55% of its $38.6 billion of revenue outside the U.S.“We have a big manufacturing base in those places; we try to source as much as we can locally and pay in local currency,” Szlosek said. “That is a nice offset.”

POMONA, Calif. — A humanoid robot built by engineers in South Korea beat out robots backed by Google (GOOGL), Amazon.com (AMZN) and top U.S. technology schools to win the $2 million grand prize in the Darpa Robotics Challenge (DRC) on Saturday.

The U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (Darpa) sponsored the Darpa Robotics Challenge to spur the development of robots that can save lives after natural and man-made disasters. Japan's Fukushima nuclear reactor meltdown in 2011 was a call to action for the competition.

Robot DRC-Hubo from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) and its spinoff company Rainbow completed all eight assignments in a simulated disaster-response mission in less than 45 minutes.

A robot named Running Man from the Florida Institute for Human & Machine Cognition (IHMC) came in second to claim the competition's $1 million prize. Running Man, built by Google-owned Boston Dynamics, finished the eight tasks in just over 50 minutes. The IHMC robot was sponsored by Amazon and collaboration software maker Atlassian.

Carnegie Mellon University's National Robotics Engineering Center finished third and won the $500,000 prize. Its robot, called CHIMP (short for CMU Highly Intelligent Mobile Platform), completed the eight tasks in a little over 55 minutes.
CMU's robot had more sponsors than a Nascar race car. It listed 20 of them, including Amazon, Foxconn, Google, Honeywell (HON), Oshkosh (OSK) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA).
Google, Amazon keen on robots

Six teams in the competition used the bipedal Atlas robot made by Boston Dynamics, a company that Google purchased in December 2013. Boston Dynamics also entertained the DRC crowd at the Fairplex fairgrounds with demonstrations of its fast-moving quadrupedal robots BigDog and Cheetah.
Google has acquired at least seven robotics companies but has not disclosed its plans for their technology.

E-commerce leader Amazon uses robots in its warehouses and is developing unmanned aerial drones for product deliveries. Amazon bought Kiva Systems, a maker of mobile robotic fulfillment systems, in March 2012 for $775 million.

Last week, Amazon held a competition to determine the state of the art in automated robots for picking items off warehouse shelves. A team from the Technology University of Berlin won the first-place prize of $20,000, tech website the Verge reported.

Jun Ho Oh, a professor of mechanical engineering at KAIST and team leader at the DRC, said that Darpa challenges are "the Olympics of robotic engineering." He said that he hopes KAIST's victory will put South Korea in the same league as robotics leaders Japan and the U.S.
Darpa director Arati Prabhakar told the teams at DRC that they are on the verge of an important industry.

"You are going to be the vanguard of this new future that you're going to go build that allows us to have robots out in unstructured environments," she said. "You're going to have the opportunity to build an entire field."
Robots come in peace
Gill Pratt, program manager for the Darpa Robotics Challenge, said, "We've shown the world just a little bit, a tiny bit, of what's possible" in robotics.

One surprising aspect of the DRC competition was the response of attendees to the robots, Pratt said. They cheered when the robots completed simple tasks and felt bad when they toppled over or otherwise failed.

"We have robots that look like the Terminator. They're built out of steel, and some of them are 6 and a half feet tall and weigh up to 443 pounds," he said. "You would have assumed that the many thousands of spectators we had would have been filled with visions of fear and anxiety. In the news, all we hear about are 'Robots are going to take over the world; they're going to kill all of us; we should run away.'"
But the crowd at the Fairplex showed empathy and sympathy for the robots, he said.
"There is a new discovery we made here, besides all the technology," Pratt said. "There's an incredible untapped affinity between people and robots."

Pratt said that he can envision robots as human companions, especially for the elderly.POMONA, Calif. — A humanoid robot built by engineers in South Korea beat out robots backed by Google (GOOGL), Amazon.com (AMZN) and top U.S. technology schools to win the $2 million grand prize in the Darpa Robotics Challenge (DRC) on Saturday.The U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (Darpa) sponsored the Darpa Robotics Challenge to spur the development of robots that can save lives after natural and man-made disasters. Japan's Fukushima nuclear reactor meltdown in 2011 was a call to action for the competition.Robot DRC-Hubo from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) and its spinoff company Rainbow completed all eight assignments in a simulated disaster-response mission in less than 45 minutes.A robot named Running Man from the Florida Institute for Human & Machine Cognition (IHMC) came in second to claim the competition's $1 million prize.
